As a child I was a huge fan of agricultural machinery even though I didn't grow up on a farm. A family member once tried to show me a video of the game, but my mom had blocked al game related stuff on the family computer lol. In high school a friend of my introduced me again to game through sl1pg8rs YouTube videos. I started watching more Farming Simulator videos and decided I wanted the next release (Farming Simulator 17). After begging my parents for a long time, they gave in and bought the disc version for the family computer (which had a hard time running the game haha). A few years ago, I decided to bring back some memory’s and buy the game again on steam (this time running the game without stuttering lol). At this moment the base game is almost perfect (no glitches on windows 10), cheap and family friendly, in other words this amazing piece of nostalgia is still a great example of what a farming game should look like.

I love farming simulator 17 dearly.

When I was a child at my grandmas house for thanksgiving, I was sitting on the couch watching my cousin play farming simulator 17 on the xbox. This was new to me, and I was instantly intriqued. The graphics, the cool controller, This was like rocket science to me. So you imagine I was obsessed with the xbox 360 and that game. I yearned for holding that controller and fucking harvesting crops. You can imagine that christmas, I only wanted that, and of course, farming simulator. That christmas when I woke up, I saw that xbox sized shape under the tree, but of course that was to be opened last. I ripped through the presents, anticipating the second I got my 7-something year old hands on the xbox 360. My first ever console. Finally, 2 presents remained. I grabbed the 2nd to last one, i ripped it open. FARMING SIMULATOR! but for the xbox one? Maybe its a mistake. I got the xbox 360, right? I finally got to the xbox.  I ripped it open like a damn feral racoon. Wait..this isnt the xbox 360? I defied physics and nearly did a double jump in the air as my brain processed that it was not the xbox 360, but the xbox one. The box looked beautiful. My first ever console. Every minute after i opened that box was hell for my parents as I begged to set it up. Eventually they caved and brought out an old tv from the garage. We plopped it down on my dresser, and we hooked up the wires. That beautiful essense of a sound flooded my ears as the green and white colors overwhelmed my eyes. We put in the batteries, and then.. I held the controller.. It was so cool, Once the lengthly setting up session was over with, I put in farming simulator 17. It felt like nearly an eternity before the game was downloaded, but my happiness did not waive! Once that little jingle played, i clicked on the game as fast as I could, and I heard that menu song. Like music to my ears, quite literally. I was glued to my xbox for a few hours at least until we had to go eat dinner. I was obsessed with that game for roughly 7 months, and gradually forgot about it. (Not my xbox though!)
Time skip to about 4 years later in 2020-2021, We couldnt afford a christmas that year or to do much, So i saved my pocket money for the brand new series X. Although I didnt need it, I still wanted it. By the first of december, i had 450$. To my suprise, My Dad agreed to pay for the rest, but i had to wait until christmas. Fine! As I looked on amazon for a gift for my parents and sister, I stumbled across farming simulator 20. Memories  flooded back. but woah, way too expensive. I looked and found last years version, farming simulator 19! I added it to my cart. I pressed buy, along with the gifts I had bought and a roll of wrapping paper. Then, christmas came. My mom fell ill and was in the hospital, so it was just me, my dad, and sister. I didnt feel like opening presents without my mom, but we did it on a facetime. Even though I knew that i had got one, I saw my 2 presents on the floor, unfortunately not under a tree this year, but That didnt matter. I ripped it open, along with farming simulator 19. I played that for a while, and watched farming simulator videos from my favorite youtubers as I waited in the hospital waiting room some days/nights. 

Janurary 15th, and my mom is released from the hospital. Thank god for those doctors who saved her life. Farming simulator helped me get through a lot as a kid and then. 5 months ago, I popped in farming simulator 17 to play it again. This game held some good, but bad memories. A single tear of happiness fell from my eye as I popped it in. Unfortunately, The disc was too scratched to be playable. Not much suprise, The disc is almost 7 years old. I had to save money anyway for my dads birthday, So i forgot about my xbox for a while. 

Now im here writing this.
Last night, I saw farming simulator 17 on steam. I could afford the newest one, but I wanted farming simulator 17. I popped in some card info, and boom. I played that for a WHILE last night.

To make a long story short, Farming simulator 17 played a big role in my life, and im grateful for it.  I know no ones reading this, but if the developers see this, thank you. :)

First of all I would like to say that I was maliciously forced into writing this review by Steam, in order to get the Autumn Sale Steam Badge 2016 (just making my parents proud). So if you've got any complaints, blame Valve!

Well FS 17 is obviously about farming if you haven't sussed it out so far! Modern farming. Modern farming with modern farming machines getting bigger and bigger as you progress. Yee-Haw! 
But it's not simply about driving up and down your fields in a tractor. It's a solid management game (mainly money): Should I buy a bigger plough (or plow if you like), sower or harvester? The plough might simply catch up with the harvester, making it unnecessary. Or should it be a 2nd harvester or another field? Should I take up a bigger loan in order to get both? Or should I simply pay off my loan first? Etc...
As time progresses you'll have more and more to take care of. It won't only be the work on the fields, checking the market for prices and handling you're braindead workers, but you might also be taking care of your animals (chicken, pigs, sheep and cows), driving X from A to B, doing the odd forestry, picking up hay bales you previously ran over, making plans on where to place your next investment, or simply sitting in a tractor with a worker inside and watch him do his work „Because I can afford it now“. Once you get the hand of the game, it quite self-explanatory.

It's slow paced, grindy, zen-like gameplay. So don't expect to be owning the best equipment within the first few hours of the game. Great often afk / halfway playing game: While playing you can easily listen to music (in-game radio is available), watch any series or sports, ignore your sister on Skype because you're trying to drive perfect lines, or simply think about stuff like the history of dog food.
I have most of my hours in MP: It's just so relaxing to drive up and down the fields with your co-farmers, honk every time you cross one another and pick up the odd machine fight because that same careless idiot touched you once again.
Easy time management in SP or with admin rights on a dedicated server (real time  - 120x). Servers are fairly cheap compared to other games.
There are two available maps at the moment. An American (according to the many stars and stripes) and a Russian (I only assume it's Russian, you know, Cyrillic stuff).
You've got a fair amount of official mods to choose from within the good in-game mod menu. Sadly they do not update automatically. It also would be handy if one could automatically download any needed mod once logging on to a new server. 

Something I really miss is seasons! Snow, hail and rain do exist, but there are no real seasons with different crops to grow or any other preparations to take care of.

Obviously I can't recommend this game to everybody. The first time I came across this franchise I shook my head in disbelief asking myself “What kind of freaks play this game?” Little did I know I would become such a freak. But that's it: you have to be the player who likes relaxing games with slow progress. Who knows? There might just be that little farmer hiding somewhere within you (you'll find it out soon enough, otherwise Steam refund policy).

You might just end up having a blast of a time in the economic branch which is the backbone of our civilization. The surplus of food over thousands of years combined with the many inventions leading to the very fact that you are now sitting on your lazy arse, staring at your screen and just wasted a few minutes of your precious life reading my lousy review about a farming simulator instead of roaming the fields and woods in search for edible roots and berries.

Thanks for the Autumn Sale Steam Badge 2016!! (and all the other ones...)

P.S Nuke the whales!!

Farming Simulator 17 is an immersive agricultural simulation game that provides players with a unique experience of managing their own farm. The game captivates with detailed graphics, a realistic model of crop cultivation and animal husbandry, and a rich agricultural ecosystem.

One of its major strengths is the extensive fleet of farming vehicles, ranging from tractors to combine harvesters. The diversity of equipment gives players full control over the processes of cultivation, harvest, and farm management.

The game also offers a variety of landscapes and seasons, influencing agricultural processes. The dynamic shift between seasons forces players to adapt their strategies, adding challenges and depth to the gameplay.

The interaction with the environment and attention to detail make "Farming Simulator 17" appealing to both fans of farming simulations and those seeking a realistic virtual farming experience. While the game's specific gameplay style may not appeal to everyone, for enthusiasts of the genre, it provides an unforgettable experience with a touch of educational elements.

Whilst this is a fun and playable game, I can't recommend it to anyone, purely because of a single bug and the complete lack of support from the developer to address it.  For whatever reason, when you start the game, it attempts to connect to some network server, fails and crashes.  Hence the only way to play the game is by first disconnecting the internet so it starts up local only.  As such Achievements don't work and mod's don't work.  It would seem a simple fix by the developer, but they seem totally uninterested in supporting a 5 year old game.  Hence I strongly recommend not buying this version of the game.

A Bountiful Harvest of Fun: Farming Simulator 17 Review

Introduction:
Farming Simulator 17 is a game that truly cultivates an immersive farming experience. As a virtual farmer, players can plow fields, tend to livestock, and engage in all aspects of agricultural life. With its realistic mechanics, stunning visuals, and a plethora of activities, this game captures the essence of farming like no other. Join me as I share my thoughts on why Farming Simulator 17 is an outstanding title for both enthusiasts and newcomers to the genre.

Gameplay:
Farming Simulator 17 offers a comprehensive and authentic farming experience. From managing crops, harvesting yields, and selling produce to raising livestock and operating a wide range of farming machinery, the game provides a remarkable level of detail. The controls are intuitive, making it accessible to players of all skill levels. The sense of accomplishment that comes from watching your farm grow and flourish is immensely satisfying, creating a rewarding gameplay loop that keeps you engaged for hours on end.

Realism:
One of the standout features of Farming Simulator 17 is its attention to realism. The game meticulously replicates the intricacies of farming, from the physics of driving tractors and other vehicles to the lifelike behavior of crops and animals. The inclusion of licensed machinery from renowned manufacturers further enhances the authenticity, allowing players to operate iconic farming equipment. Whether you're sowing seeds, spraying fields, or baling hay, the attention to detail in every aspect of the game is commendable.

Variety and Freedom:
Farming Simulator 17 offers an impressive variety of activities and features. You can choose to specialize in different types of farming, such as crop cultivation, livestock rearing, or even forestry. The game world is expansive, providing vast landscapes to explore and cultivate. Additionally, the inclusion of a multiplayer mode allows you to collaborate with friends and tackle farming challenges together, adding a social dimension to the experience. The freedom to play at your own pace and pursue various farming ventures makes each playthrough unique and enjoyable.

Visuals and Sound:
Visually, Farming Simulator 17 is a treat for the eyes. The game boasts stunning environments, with beautifully rendered fields, detailed machinery, and atmospheric weather effects. The changing seasons add a layer of realism, as crops evolve and landscapes transform accordingly. The ambient sounds of nature and the satisfying hum of machinery further immerse players in the farming world, enhancing the overall experience.

Modding Community:
One of the greatest strengths of Farming Simulator 17 is its thriving modding community. The game supports a wide range of user-created mods, allowing players to customize and expand their farming experience. Whether it's adding new crops, introducing additional machinery, or enhancing the game's visuals, the modding community continually enriches the content and longevity of the game. The ability to personalize your farm and tailor the gameplay to your liking is a testament to the game's versatility.

Conclusion:
Farming Simulator 17 is a gem of a game that successfully captures the essence of the farming lifestyle. With its immersive gameplay, realistic mechanics, and stunning visuals, it provides an engaging and rewarding experience for players. The wide range of activities, attention to detail, and the support of a vibrant modding community make it a game that can be enjoyed for countless hours. Whether you're a farming enthusiast or someone looking to try something new, Farming Simulator 17 offers an excellent farming adventure that will leave you yearning for more.

Interesting game. Excellent choice for a game if you just want to relax and role play being a farmer. Its an excellent insight into how farming is done. Its only £13 too for the base game. DLC should only be bought if you've put 100s of hours into the game and want more content. But if that's the case, just go and buy farm simulator 19 or 22. I bought this because there wasn't a demo for any of the games and this was the newest, cheapest option. I got my money's worth. 
19 and 22 have more features of course. But this game is worth it if you just want to see if you'll like this type of game. "But there's a refund window," you say? It takes hours upon hours to really get a feel for this type of game so 2 hours really isn't enough. 

It takes that long to cultivate 1 large field!!!

I can now say without a doubt that I do like this type of game. I was looking for a relaxing game to listen to podcasts to. This is that type of game. 

I think I'll buy 19 next. Or maybe go straight to 22...

Ok, so this version of the game is getting a bit long in the tooth. Despite that, I love it, with superb graphics, playability and wide range of equipment options. I discovered all the community mods the other day, so there is even more to get one's teeth into and play around with. I play this at 4k and it is superb, so not really sure what the newer FS19 and FS22 are bringing to the party? I will definitely have a go at those though when the price is right! 

The only negative about this sim is that it accurately portrays the grind, boredom, and sheer hard work of farming. Paying for hired help is essential to relieve that. 

Latterly I have imagined Jeremy Clarkson playing this farming sim and it inspiring him to do it for real ???!!

7/10 - GOOD!

Very chill farming simulator. No quests and no storyline. You decide what you want to do, what to grow, what to buy and what to sell. Engine and graphics are getting a bit old now comparing to the latest release of this franchise, but if you see this on sale for $10, grab it and spend a few dozen hours just chilling and relaxing while farming some crops.

dies ist eine review zum landwirtschafts simulator 17 ich werde erst das gute aufzählen und dann das negative also fangen wir an

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

spielzeit : 979 std.

gut/schlecht verhältnis : 95% / 5%
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

die 95 % guten dinge :

- die grafik : das spiel sieht auf seine eigene art richtig gut aus es wirkt auch sehr beruhigend und dank der vielen einstellungen läuft es auch auf jeder kartoffel ich meine es lief auf meinen alten rechner der von einem fetten hamster angetrieben wurde

- das wetter : das spiel hat ohne mods 5 wetter arten ( sonnig, bedeckt, nebel, regen und hagel ) mit verschiedenen realistischen auswirkungen so kann man z.b nicht bei regen ernten

- große fahrzeug auswahl : vom normalen traktor über hoch moderne kartoffel ernte maschinen  bis hin zum forst werkzeug und fahrzeuge zur tier pflege ist alles mit drin von orginal herstellern und einer orginal getreuen innen perspektive

- tiere : man kann sich um 3 arten von tieren kümmern wenn man will ( kühe, schafe und schweine ) mit sie sind echt süß und produzieren auch dinge wenn sie glücklich sind und ich persönlich schau gern kühen beim grasen zu 

- reale feld bearbeitung : das spiel ist sehr realistisch was die feld bewirtschaftung angeht so muss man pflügen, sähen, ernten und grubbern und zwischendurch mal richtig durch düngen 

- die sounds : die sounds im spiel sind erste sahne die fahrzeuge hören sich orginal getreu an und auch die natur geräusche sind echt entspannend da kommt man mal zur ruhe auch die tier geräusche sind richtig gut

- entscheidungs freiheit : dass spiel bindet dich an garnix du kannst machen was immer du willst

- große frucht auswahl : das spiel hat eine ganze palette von früchten die man anpflanzen kann ( weizen, gerste, raps, mais, soja bohnen, sonnenblumen, zuckerrüben, kartoffeln und pappeln ) 

- helfer : das spiel stellt einen bei bedarf helfer zur verfügung für denn fall das du alleine spielst diese kosten zwar ingame geld aber nicht viel sie können z.b ein feld für dich pflügen

- sehr mod freundlich : das spiel ist sehr mod freundlich und es hat auch sehr viele zur auswahl und auch einen eigenen mod manager 

- gute community : die community die das spielt ist meiner meinung sehr nett und hilfreich

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

die 5% schlechten dinge :

- wetter effekte : leider hat das spiel keinen scheiben aspekt was heißt man wird bei regen leider keine regen tropfen auf denn scheiben an fahrzeugen sehen die man weg wischen müsste 

- manchmal dummer helfer : manchmal kann es vorkommen das helfer fest stecken oder denken sie währen fertig das passiert aber meistens nur selten

- wenig tier interaktion : was ich auch vermisse sind dinge wie melken oder scheren der schafe oder sowas wie ne schaufel so das man nicht immer großes gerät braucht zum versorgen

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


hier noch ein kleiner einblick was alles so drin ist : https://youtu.be/HvgBkobjgdY

so dass wärs kann das spiel jedem empfehlen auch jemanden der in die landwirschaft rein schnuppern will oder einfach nur ein spiel zum entspannen will
sollten noch fragen offen sein dann schreibt sie gern in die kommentare ich versuch sie zu beantworten,

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

dear reader,

this is a review to the farming simulator 17 firstly i will focus on the good things and later on the bad stuff, lets do this

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

playing time : 979  hours

good bad difference : 95% / 5%

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

the 95% good stuff :

- the grafic : the game looks really good on his own and its really relaxing too and it have many settings so that it works on ever pc i mean it worked on my old pc and that main engine was a fat hamster

- the weather : the game have 5 difference weather effects ( sunny, covered, fog, rain and hail ) with different realistic effects so you can as exemple not harvest when its rain

- many vehicles : from the little tractor over modern potato harvest machinery to the wood harvest stuff is everything in there are vehicles for animals too they all from orignal manufacturers with a orginal look

- animals : there 3 animal typs ingame you can take care ( cows, sheeps and pigs ) they look sweet and they product stuff to when they happy and what can be better as watching a cow grazing

- real farming : the game is really realistic when it comes to the field stuff you must plow, sow, harvest and cultivate and dont forget to fertilize real hard

- the sounds : the sounds ingame are great the vehicles sounds realistic and the nature sounds really relaxing too and the animal sounds are good too

- do what you want : the game let you do what ever you want 

- many stuff to plant : the game have a many plants you can plant ( wheat, barley, rapeseed, corn, soybeans, sugar beet,potatos and poplars )

- helpers : the game let you hire helpers for the work they cost ingame money but not so much they can for you plow a field for you as example

- very mod friendly : the game is very mod friendly and have much mods too it even have his own mod manager

- the community : the community in the game is very friendly and helpfull
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

the 5% bad things :

- the weather effects : sadly the game dont have a window mechanic what means there dont be rain drops at the windows in vehicles

- sometimes stupid helpers : it can be happening that helpers stuck somewere or thing they done but they dont but that happening not very much 

- less animal interactions : i miss a bit stuff like milking cows or shearing sheeps or a shovel that you dont need heavy stuff to feed your animals

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

here you have a little video whats in the game : https://youtu.be/HvgBkobjgdY'


so thats all i can recommend this game everybody even the ones that just wanna look how farming works or just wanna relax ingame

when there are more questions about the game then feel free to ask in the comment section i try to answer them,

Farming Simulator 17. Worth, Every, Penny, Period.


Farming Simulator 17, the game so great i constantly come back to it instead of FS19.

(Warning your entering FS17 VS FS19 rant, if you prefer to skip i will put a marker named TL:DR for Pros and Cons)

FS17 is what i would consider the last true FS17 game. FS19 for its better graphics and John Deere dog whistle for Americans like me isn't enough.

 FS19 vehicle colorization isn't that realistic, engine sounds, horns,  and other sounds don't seem half as good. FS19 seems like a sissyfication of farming in FS19, it tends to fit the theme of Greta Thunberg farming. FS17 seems to fit the classic theme of farming and gives rustic buildings and tractors a realistic charm that FS19 cannot match. 

The modding community seems to be stronger in FS17 than FS19. FS17 allows for a larger fleet of mod vehicles.

You can throw up that bullcrap about better graphics and features all you want, but not everyone runs to a game for fancy graphics. I guess i have always had a bias towards FS17 since it was my first FS game, i have tried FS15 and love it about the same. 

FS19 also had a lazily made American map vs FS17. Giants could've done better with FS19 and the American map than they did. Generally when a American makes a European map for a game i would tend to expresses the best qualities of the scenery in said country. I just expect to an extent them to do the same since they made a decent map before.

(TL:DR)

Pro's: 
-Relaxing experience
-More machines than previous games
-More quality mods than FS19
-Great American map compared to FS19

Con's:
-Too many overpriced machines ingame
-Some mods can be too overpowered (Not the games fault as much as some of the modders :] )
-Not enough smaller machines

Overall FS17 is a great game if you do not mind missing out on some of the bells and whistles of FS19, also i suggest you check of FS15 if you want something similar, but cheaper.

Update: I have tried FS22, i think its an improvement over FS19. So FS22 might be worth trying.

[h1]WARNING! for Intel users[/h1]

Hello, I love this game and I had a lot of fun hours in it in the past. unfortunately on a newer PC I got there is an issue that crash the game at start up, most likely related to the game's Modhub that is integrated inside it. I read that it is a known issue related to certain Intel processors. there is a reason why you would want an older farming simulator game, for hardware limitation or better prices. the game is fun from farming simulator 2013 inward at least for me.

The game does work for me now after blocking all game communication to the internet, though I will not be bothering playing it online. alternatively you can just cut the internet until you are in game. OR get farming simulator 19 or 22 if they are in a decent price. I've known Giant Games to stand by their products. and I am surprised they ignored this issue so far. 

Good luck and happy farming, or foresting !
very cool game
i LIKE THE GAME

Coming from Farming Simulator 15, I was amazed to see this game. It is miles beyond 15 definitely in the world, how things work. Much much better

Now, will say there are drawbacks. Buying and selling I think was altered to majorly balance the game with this vs perhaps real prices that 15 actually had

1. Forestry is majorly nerfed from being able to make pretty good profit continuously from. Now, it went from a high amount, to a low sum per
2. Silage as well got cut by 1000x. So no more quick money schemes with this one

Farming honestly is the only fastest option ive seen in this game to make money. So I'll admit that did disappoint me a bit. As to balance the game the alternative ways of money making became stripped basically to the point that this literally is a: Farming Simulator

I like that things are better and easier for all in this game. Silage you can do with helpers now. Farming as well has a bit more help

Trucks now aren't a minimum of 200,000 to buy. You can get them from I think 120-170? I think its around there.

The game also gives you A LOT more to buy and use.

Getting silage as well is actually A LOT faster in this game. So will say that despite the almost insane cutback to kill it, they do compensate with the speed at least in a small way vs the cut. Can make 100,000 silage in the time it takes to mow and windrow 1 field basically. 

I will say it becomes much faster to start as the game does compensate for the cuts, a bit, by providing this: A golden nugget search

Right from the beginning what I'd recommend to get a fast start is to find the golden nuggets. It's not too hard, find a guide online on youtube to find 10, then the rest show on your map. Track them all down and you get a million dollars. Thanks to that you get a major jumpstart on how you want to play your game.

Now, there are small glitches in the game. Nothing major that will hurt the game experience where you'll stop playing. Only ones ive really found so far are:

1. Helpers when they are told to fertilize, or etc, will occasionally randomly find some other way to deal with the field, or row, vs what you would've planned. For instance, usually you'll do straight rows the longest way across a field. Randomly when you start the helper they will go the other direction. For fertilizing, theyll even leave some parts undone. Just the last part to clarify. It's a little annoying. Nothing too major as its easy do it yourself stuff on occasion, but small annoyances nonetheless

2. When filling a trailer with grain, etc, on rare occasion the trailer will look like its shaking and about to fall over, glitching out on screen, and can hit your vehicle. It's very very weird. It rumbles and eventually after it fully flips out, goes back to normal. Literally looks like a seizure on screen.

Other than these though, not really much that I've noticed

Small glitches, some major money changes, but still LOTS of improvements to the game allowing for far more than you could do in 15

I still plan to go through the games in order, to be able to enjoy them, and still be able to come back to them having played them, rather than get spoiled on all the features in later games and never be able to enjoy what the games before had

Mary Berry's Banoffee Pie:
Ingredients

For the base

150g/5½ oz digestive biscuits (about 10)
75g/2¾oz butter
For the toffee filling
75g/2¾oz butter
75g/2¾oz light muscovado sugar
1 x 397g/14oz full-fat condensed milk (see tip)
1 tsp vanilla extract
For the topping
300ml/10fl oz double cream
3 small just-ripe bananas, sliced
50g/1¾oz dark chocolate, melted or cocoa powder

Method

Line the base of a deep 20cm/8in spring form tin with baking paper.

To make the base, crush the biscuits to fine crumbs and melt the butter over a low heat. Pour into a bowl and mix to combine. Spoon into the base of the tin and press down with the back of a spoon until level. Place in the fridge for 15 minutes.

To make the filling, heat the butter and sugar in a small non-stick saucepan and stir over a low heat until combined. Add the condensed milk and bring to the boil, stirring for 2–3 minutes – do not over-boil or it will become grainy and fudge-like. Add the vanilla and pour into the tin. Place in the fridge for at least 1 hour.

Whip the cream in a bowl until soft peaks form.

Arrange the banana slices in neat rounds on top of the toffee. Spoon or pipe the cream on top and level. Set in the fridge for an hour.

Remove from the tin, and zig zag the melted chocolate over the top or dust with cocoa powder.

(Summary at bottom)
NOT a reskinned FS19. I have about 650 hours on FS19 and I can most certainly say this is much better in many ways, and many things have been completely overhauled.

- Sounds have had a major overhaul, makes the game feel more realistic and immersive.
- More placeables than ever, including sheds with working doors, refuel stations (diesel, methane, and electric), seed & fert tanks, etc. Fences too, great addon, easy to use.
- Many many new brands, and more tire brand options. Also license plates for equipment and vehicles.
- Character customization. Graphics wise, it looks a rather bit weird, but I'm sure it'll be improved. Unfortunately you have to change the character per-savegame, not any sort of preset in the main menu.
- Better organized XML files. Much more easier on the eyes compared to FS17, and easier to find things such as the money value. I don't need to use ctrl+f anymore, I can just scroll. (Speaking of XML editing, instead of editing the careerSavegame.xml file like FS17 & FS19 to add cash, here you need to edit farms.xml file instead in the same folder, careerSavegame.xml is only for appearance in the main menu.)
- Better organized shop UI, not to mention the UI overall. Imo, the weird blue fade on the speedometer/tachometer reminds me of the ol' FS13 UI, kinda wish it was more clean and simplistic as the FS19 UI, but hey, it is what it is.
- American-based map. Major improvement from Ravenport and Goldcrest Valley, feels more of the true american countryside thanks to that new office here in the U.S. that Giants got a while ago.
- Buying used equipment. As of now it seems limited to 4 pieces of equipment at a time, but very neat feature regardless.
- Vehicle gearbox. Not required if you don't want to use it, but I like it. A wee bit confusing at times however, I'm used to the way you shift in American Truck Simulator, but this is different. Not bad, maybe needs to be tweaked a bit.
- Obviously graphics, you won't really notice a huge jump between FS19 and FS22 as the major jump of the franchise was between FS17 and FS19, but there is some noticeable changes.
- Seasons. I don't like playing so realistic to the point I have to wait time for the proper planting and harvesting time, but there's an option to make it so the seasons are just visual only. You can also make it so it's one season at all times.

Now, there are of course many bugs with the game, and some features missing since it just got released today, but I'm pretty sure Giants will get most of them sorted out before the next year.

Some rather aggravating bugs/missing features are:
- Inability to remove buildings and fences on farms that already exist on the map. I have only tested this on Elmcreek so far, however, but it is most likely this applies to all other maps.
- Landscaping, a wee bit glitchy, controls are difficult to get used to from FS19. Can't sprint in landscaping mode.
- AI workers. We all know from previous FS games that the AI is notorious, especially in FS17. Here, there have been some improvements, and with the addition of AI being able to drive vehicles to and fro, that's really useful, but again, very buggy. The classic 'Helper F is blocked by an object!' pops up every now and then, you tab over and there's like nothing in it's way.
- With some vehicles, most notably (and only tested on so far,) is the Mack Anthem. It's not a true 6x4, more of a 6x2. I was hauling the largest CLAAS wheel loader & the 4755 with rear duals on the non-Lodeking flatbed up a hill, it almost seemed as if the rear axle of the Anthem was going backwards, whereas the front rear axle was slipping. Fine, maybe it doesn't have a lockable transfer case of diffs, but it should go up that hill with the most powerful engine in it, plus the weight on the rear axles from the fifth wheel.
- Buildings, most notably the farmhouse. If you look into the windows, it's just a copied .jpeg of a weird looking kitchen with yellow cabinets and a granite looking wall. I'm sure Giants will add in an interior at some point, I don't want buildings to start to function like the ones back in FS13. Also , you cannot interact/enter any existing buildings/sheds/barns on the farms on the land you purchase. I sure hope that gets fixed.

Bugs TL;DR:
- Existing Building Removal (Cannot remove them, this includes existing fences.)
- Existing Building Functionality (Cannot enter buildings and cannot open shed/barn doors)
- Landscaping (Buggy, a minor visual glitch, & controls are awkward)
- AI Driving/Transport (Blocked by basically nothing or drives the wrong path)

TL;DR:

There are many bugs, I hope they'll be fixed before the next year. But there are also many improvements from previous FS games, as someone who's played FS13 (Xbox 360), 17 (Steam), and 19 (Epic Games).

At this time, with the amount of bugs/missing features in the game, I would just wait and get it on sale in the future.
If you're someone who already purchased it, don't bother refunding it, just wait for the bugs to be worked out.

I have not tested everything, and I have not played every map. I do not have all of the bugs and missing features listed, I will update this review as I come across more notable bugs, missing features, and good changes from previous FS games.

Again, this is a newly released game, so unless Giants decides to not fix these issues/keep them removed like EA did with Battlefield 2042, then I will change this review as needed.

What I like about this game is how it teaches a person the required procedures or methods to farming.  
Though this game, one can earn money quickly, however if played as in real life, patience is a virtue. 
Also this game shows the many ways; if one was to take on farming in real life,  in which to earn an income. As well, the benefit to hiring farm hands that will allow the farmer to accomplish other chores, preparing another field or the feeding and caring of livestock. Though many attachments are automatic, in real farming not so much; many hook ups are done manually. Still what one can learn to farming from this game is gratifying. Follow the process of growing crops and the feeding of livestock, one can succeed with much profit. So play this game to learn or just for fun, but all in all, you will learn about farming from this awesome automated game.

I'm Going To Go Through A Classic Pros And Cons list Then move To Final Notes, Ready? Go.

---------------------------------------------------

Pros: 

-A Lot Of Potential Content And Very Fun For Discord Friend Groups, Good Gameplay With A Theraputic Simpliticity To It, For The Most Part, Featuring A Very Large Variety Of Methods To Get Wealthy.

-The Game's DLC Content Is Absolutely Amazing And I Loved Every Second Of Having It, Highly Recommended

-Relatively Nice Community When You Manage To Talk To Adults That Are From Your Country (The Game's Community Is Completely Dead, Don't Expect To Find People Other Than Little Kids With Money Mods)

-Absolutely Beautiful Atmosphere With A Lot Of Effort Put Into It, Both Singleplayer Easter Eggs And Tips And In Multiplayer


-EXTREMELY Good Modding Community, There Are Entire Websites Dedicated To Mods For This Game And Some Of Them Are Truly Gems To Behold

---------------------------------------------------

Cons:

-This Game's Community Is Dead, And The Community Is Pretty Much Nothing But Money Mod Kids That Give Themselves 999999999999 Money To Buy Whatever They Want, Completely Removing The Game's Purpose From The Games Purpose.

-Casual Audience, Mostly 10 And Younger, Selfish, And Bad, They Don't Know How To Use Systems Like Recovering Vehicles From Lakes With The Anti Greif Tools.

-Not Enough Anti Greifer Tools, People Can Make Horribly Ugly Field Edits For No Reason With Zero Punishment

-The Ban System DOES NOT WORK AT ALL BECAUSE RETARDED DEVELOPERS, The Bans Only Last For The Current Game Session, Which Means Greifers That Log In Daily Have To Re-Banned Every Day, And Its Usually Harder Because They Change Names Regularly For No Punishment.

TLDR: The Game Doesnt Remember Who You Ban And Will Unban Them Next Time You Start The Server

---------------------------------------------------

Notes:

Farming Simulator Game's Get Micro Improvements Every Year, And This Game Is The Best Of Its Era (The Newer Versions Have A Functioning Banlist Though) And The Game Went Through Drastic Changes last Year, And I Believe It Was For The Worse, As It Turned Computers Into Ovens And Implemented A Really Poorly Designed Building And Terrain Editor.

The game does not launch when connected to the internet. Disabling your adapter or unplugging ethernet from your computer will allow it to launch, but that shouldn't be a solution. This problem has been popping up in the forums for months and there hasn't been a response from the developers or, better yet, an update to fix the problem. There doesn't seem to be any other solutions such as ensuring firewall exceptions are present. 

Original review below:

I got FS17 after playing FS15 for a long time, and I can say for sure that FS17 was a big step forward from FS15. It adds so many new details and polishes that really make the game feel more complete. I would say the most important step to that end was promoting a more integrated stance towards mods. The in-game mod management is nearly flawless (limited in my opinion by its lack luster and over-simplified GUI, but that's to be expected if it's going to work on consoles) that offers many expansions in the area of quality. 

The areas that I would say this game is limited comes from some of the clear limitations of graphics and ground display systems. While this is leagues more convincing that FS15 in terms of physics and graphics, I still deeply desire a more comprehensive physics and graphics system. In the physics department, I think I've narrowed down the main reason for my disappointment is around how the camera is affected by the physics. (Forgive me if this is a camera mode I could change, but I didn't find a way to change this.) The camera is completely static, regardless if you're traveling 25MPH on a flat road, or traveling 40MPH off road. I've seen examples where I am taken out of the immersion as I do a jump in a fast tractor (on my happy free play save) and the camera shows no emotion. There are a few explanations to why some people wouldn't like camera reaction to physics events, but I would simply ask for a toggle to enable / disable it. 

The graphics and ground response are also disappointing. The best animations for farm equipment seem to be from stalk crops being harvested by a combine. You can see the stocks line up (crudely) and guide into the blades. However, when it comes to the rest of the tools, there is no illusion or distraction from the cut-and-dry status of worked fields. Things disappear and appear exactly with no gradual application. Overall, yes, this much improves over FS15, but I want more. 

I have not played FS19 as I read that it is mostly an incremental improvement over FS17. I await eagerly for the future Farming Simulator game and hope that it shows greater strides of improvement. Also, this review may seem mostly negative, but I assure you, the 200+ hours should indicate that I do indeed love this game. So much so that I want it to be better and more fun.

As of September 2021, this is still the best version of Farming Simulator one can buy with their money. A complete upgrade from 15's edition, this game pulls out all the stops. The introductions of AGCO, Pigs, Sunflowers and Soybeans, and much much more make this a jam-packed farming adventure that anyone can pick up. The American map is still the best Giants has ever made; with the absolutely massive fields, perfect North-West setting, and train system that eases transport of crops and lumber. The Mod Page is a massive introduction to this addition. (Mostly) Gone are the days of grabbing mods off of questionable websites and Hello to a organized list of quality mods by both Giants and others. The DLC are of good quality, with the Big Bud pack being the most massive (literally) ever made and is worth every penny. Until we get a step-up in versions like 15-->17, Farming Simulator 17 is the pinnacle of this franchise. Skip on FS19, buy FS17.

The control is smooth and graphics is still beautiful though; so if you want a relaxing game to farm, it might be for you! 
I recommend with caution!

I love this game and have many hours of enjoyment just playing it single player vanilla all 600 hours I've played have been unmodded and this game has a HUGE modding community and a decent multiplayer. This game is perfect to sit and chill mindlessly and unwind after work. There are tons of tractors and tools to try out and collect and a fairly in depth system to try and learn and make efficient. It has ok graphics but runs very well with almost no game breaking bugs.

 But this game isn't for everyone and it does have it flaws. 

One flaw is that the games physics are a bit wonky, for example you can be in the biggest tractor in the game pulling a train of heavy equipment and getting close to an AI in a compact car or a small rock in the grass will dead stop you and the AI will just drive straight into you blocking you off. However AI can be turned off in settings.

Flaw two, no NPCS buts it didn't bother me much as it is just a relaxing game.

Third flaw sometimes items just FLIP out and go flying 

Fourth flaw is that tractor types matter very little most tools are interchangeable.

I would recommend this game but do understand its not for everyone.

I consider this a low-key, low-stress game.  Fairly open and able to play at your own pace.  Stay with the just the starter fields, or expand by purchasing other fields.  It's rather easy with the base game maps to purchase all fields and eventually own the whole map.  Plant different crops.  Experiment with different equipment to determine your favorites.  The modded maps and equipment offer a nice variety once the base game becomes rather routine.  You can also choose to become a rancher, instead of or in addition to farming.  Pigs, sheep, and cows each offer their own challenges.  Play solo, or jointly work the map with friends or family.

Tried this game because it came on sale, and I was curious.  I have worked on a grain farm in the past, and thought this might be a bit fun to play with.  I was right.  If you like money-type/business games AND/OR you like open-ended peaceful type games, this one works well for that.  Very open ended - do whatever you want.  Lots of free mods you can download from inside the game to expand your equipment or give you new maps to try.

I see so many reviewers saying that it's pretty much FS15. I think that's a bit of a stretch. I personally think that there are so many new and great features in FS17. If you're on the fence, GET IT. If you're thinking you can save a few dollars and just buy 15, you'll be missing out. Spend the money on 17 and don't look back. I almost didn't make the purchase because of those reviews because I already owned 15. I'm very glad that I chose to watch some YouTube video reviews etc before closing the book on this one. So watch some videos. Look for literature that details the difference between these two games. Make an informed decision. I'm grateful I did. I can't stop thinking about this game.

Literally anyone and everyone can play this game. It's not super hard to learn even if you know very little about agriculture. Even for people who know a lot about farming there are limitless opportunities to Roleplay realistic farming. With this game it also gives you the ability to become a Organic Farmer. Whether it be Organic animal production or just crop production. The option is always there.

Story-
There is none. You create your own story with your farm. Do what you see fit to create a successful farm.

Difficult-
☐ Just press a bunch of buttons
☑ Easy
☐ Significant brain usage
☐ Easy to learn / Hard to master
☐ Not so easy
☐ Difficult
☐ Dark Souls
Very easy to learn, easy to play and a very relaxing game overall. If you want to expand to other brands like John Deere and other multifruits that are not part of the game you totally can. Your farm can be as easy, and as hard as you want to make it. Smaller equipment takes longer to do large fields. But it's cheap and can fit mostly anywhere. Bigger equipment is more expensive, but can get the job done faster. Strongly recommend getting the Old Iron IH pack as it is very realistic and really IH should have been part of the original game. Perfect for small and medium sized farms/maps. 

Grind-
☐ Nothing
☐ Only if you care about leaderboards/ranks
☐Isnt necessary to progress
☐ A bit grindy sometimes
☑  Average grind level
☐ Too much grind
☐ Insanity
Its farming which means lots of tractor work which can get boring quick. Hired workers help but they seem to not be very smart. Using something like Courseplay can really help with the grindyness and definitely help with all aspects of the farm. Especially with harvesting with something like seasons mod where your crop will die if the weather is not adequate for crop life. There are many options to help make farming easier. But tasks are very repetitive.

☑ Depends on you
☐ Endless

☐ Worth the price
☐ Wait for sale
☐ Maybe if you have some spare money left

Very good game. Best farming game out there and a Much better improvement overall in the UI and general performance and with the Proper edition of forestry, No longer are logs flying across the map and 15 FPS multiplayer lobbies. FS 15 was a complete joke but FS 17 is the best farming game yet, From Cows, Sheep, Pigs and chickens, This game has it all, many fruit types, realistic farming and many many new and awesome features. The Great thing about this game is the AMAZING Modding community that can really enhance your Farming franchise by a cataclysmic amount. Worth a buy for sure!!!.

For realistic players getting Seasons mod is a must. This game is highly modable as long as the mods are actually made proper. The Graphics are good and the game runs well on lower to higher end systems with no issue. If you have a higher end PC then you have the ability to run larger maps with more mods allowing for more larger farming operations to take place. 

Like mentioned above there is an option to organically grow crops and animals which is fantastic if you want to grow organic produce and not chemical grown produce. Soils testing is not a thing yet in this game but the the mods more than make up for that. Certain modded maps also have there own unique features and animations as well as additional fruit types and graphics mods. 

Few bugs, most bugs are often caused by mods not working or acting up. This a great game to simply relax and play with a bear in your hand. not hard at all to learn and easy to play.

A game that has switched to the new generation Farming Simulator mode. As someone who has played in FS15 and FS19 recently, I can say that there is a decisive game between the two. It is a game that is more detailed than FS15 and better adjusted in terms of FPS values. It is not a game that requires as much fine detail as the FS19. Of course, Farming Simulator will be a bit challenging for newcomers to the world. Before crying because I can't do it, be patient and continue. Make sure you don't suddenly understand how you grew up. Farming is labor after all. Not easy

This game is the pinnacle of casual, enjoyable and calming gameplay. I would recommend this 1000x over. It has a wonderful community of people and some really intelligent modding which can either enhance your enjoyment or take it away but the best thing is; that is all based on your decisions.

My advice is use modding lightly if you have the time to farm correctly and realistically, try it, and you will love this game endlessly. Overuse of exaggerated and unrealistic mods, although mega fun when you're just trying to have a laugh and be silly with your farm, can sap the fun when you become a billionaire with no real work!!

That being said, this game goes above and beyond any simulation expectation and I can honestly say that I will follow this franchise forward. GIANT software really understand their customer base and provided a game with such a wide array of free choice and option!

It's Nov 2020 and Farming Simulator 2017 is still on my PC. 

I'm 100's of hours in at this point in time and still happy I stuck to the title.

A note about FS2019
I need to be clear, I have no problem with FS2019. I didn't get FS2019 for the same reason as I didn't get FS2015 when I was playing FS2013 ... every two years a new edition drops, which, eventhough it does build on the last, doesn't always represent value for money for me. I personally treat it as a sim and as such, it take times for me to get the setup I want, find the mods I prefer, make the edits I wish to have. Then to get on with enjoying the experience I've eventually built only for a new title to drop soon after and I have to start all over again is not what I need. The second edition down the line usually packs good bang for buck, builds on it's predecessor and represents a worthwhile purchase.
So the skipped 2019 which worked for me so far.

If you are new to Farming Simulator and happen to be reading this review, (unlikely I know)  I would recommend you look at FS2019. It is the better entry point and the community have already had plently of time to build up the mod databases also.

All that said, FS2017 is still an active and enjoyable FS edition and one which I can also recommend if for some reason, FS2019 is no an option for you. You can see by the price it commands also that it's popular. 

The mod community has been very active and for those with FS2017 already, it's so good that  I personally see little reason to move on.

A future expected Farming Simulator 2021 is confirmed by Giants as not happening (at least against the expected 2-year schedule (Sept)  that the previous many editions released on).

This might prove to be a very good thing. The based title is a solid foundation. FS2017 was  a huge success and FS2019 build on that with improved graphics essentially as well as some official brand content that has been previously addressed via the mod community. 
Where Giants to have more time to enhance, Environmentals (weather, ground, crop), Tools (farming finance and mangements) and User Experience ( IC, sounds, feel) aspects, they could establish a new foundation upn which the community would get re-energised and indeed secure the future.

So Giants have done a great job and have delievered products (whether it be FS2017 or FS2019) which really present farming in both a fun arcade way as well as a simulated multi player way.

A nice way to spend som hour behind a stearing wheel.
You need to do all the basic things that a farmer need to do in order to get any income. Of course, not everyting is there, but enough to get you in the right mood.
When playing for a while you will find your self to do the same thing all over again, and the motivation and challange might be a bit low.
But as long as you like to run a tractor with a trailer, or a combine harvester, it does'nt matter.

Graphics is on a level so that it looks nice on a few years old computer.

The downside is that some of the physics are not realistic, like the forresting, timber that feel like steel beams, and a control of the fork lift that is just bad will make you frustrated. The lack of deep perception is not helping.
The same goes for e,g, bales, pallets or anything that should be moved by a fork lift.
Bales are hard as concrete and the squeecing fork do not get a good grip on that.

But, I like the concept. Hope that next version (not 19) will solve some of the material handling physics.

Great farming simulator game overall... I'd give it 4.5 stars out of 5

Pros:
- great concept, using and operating all kind of machinery and tools, specialized for mechanized farming and forestry
- land modification with fields being plowed, sowed, fertilized, and not last harvested, even creating new fields or deleting existing ones
- great balancing overall, of the money income vs. expenses, with some small exceptions here and there, but addictive enough to spend time playing the game to make money
- plenty of free mods available from mods creators in the community, some great, some good, some that need some improvement, but a wide selection to choose from 
- plenty of YouTube tutorials from more experienced players sharing their experience makes it easier to grasp the more complex aspects of the game, as it's not really a simple boring game
- quite stable, for me at least, I had no crashed, no freezing, no performance issues whatsoever, works nice and smooth as intended, even on a laptop that's not top of the line
- a build in radio player allowing us to play our own mp3s or internet radio as we choose

Cons:
- maps are small to my taste, in short time there is nothing more to explore
- in-game time is not realistic enough to my taste, I'd expect real time speed with options to speed up if and when we want - like in FSX
- no seasons build in the vanilla base game, but somewhat solved by a great mod - however, the mod is not original from the game-developers, as such is still not realistic enough, one full year is passing in maxim 23-26 game-days (if I remember correctly) and to me at least, it's still not realistic enough
- no avatar per see in-game of the character, or the workers helping the character - there is a small attempt, but it's far from having an avatar/character to explore and play
- not enough interactions with the buildings, most are plain decor, useless, can't open doors, windows, can't place-move-remove furniture or items, really 90% of the buildings are plain decor with no actual function, except silos and some storage specific buildings

Not even sure where to start man.  I got this game because I'm a sim player and the graphics looked nice, and it was on sale.  I'm in LA, so the last thing going on around me is farming, unless you're farming weed.  This game, and it's modders, BLEW MY MIND. 

You do the first two tutorials to get the gist of the controls and the basics of farming.   And it's the basics, I'm 140+ hours in and all I've done is work the fields on the first map.  No animals, I cut down a half dozen trees by chainsaw around my silos that were pissing me off because I kept ramming them, no chaff, hay, manure, blah blah blah, just joyously working the fields, learning where everything is, and buying shit (the lower three fields and better equipment so far).  To say this game is addicting, even to a city dude with zero ties or previous interest in farming, is a gross understatement.  Just playing the basics, you realize the layers of this game just go on and on, and how each crop (and animals when you get them)  interweaves with different functions of your farm, and each other, is one of the coolest applications of resource management I've seen, and I've got probably 50 RM games.

So the playability alone is endlessly challenging and engaging, but then you start adding the insane amounts of equipment that these farmers really use because certain crops need certain specialty equipment, fields of different sizes and shapes (not all of which can be worked completely with hired help), different crop cycles and crops, seasons if you want them.  It just doesn't end.

Then there's a second map to do it all over again.  Two maps normally draw a smirk from people, but all it takes is the two tutorials and 30 minutes on the first map, and you know you're in for some serious simming.

Then we go to the modding community.  I play (for better or for worse) many of the Paradox titles and their modding communities get pretty crazy in terms of tonnage and quality.  Nah, kiddie pool.  This group of modders, and I'm talking directly to all of you, are THE BEST.  It's not just such a vast array of equipment in every single category that your head explodes (there a dude modding forks for your Polish forklift for crissake!), it's the quality of the art as well.  You're farming in Poland?  No problem, every manufacturer in Poland has gear in this game from harvesters to tractors; Plows, cultivators and seeders; Tippers, tanks,  vats, spreaders, tumblers, turners, and some wind wheel thing that gathers your cut grass into a frickin line so you can gather it with some other piece of equipment.  Germany?  Sweden?  Italy?  Russia?  Got you covered, and which manufacturer did you want to purchase again?  Just so ridiculous that experienced players must be in hog heaven using all this stuff.  I can't wait to get there.  

That brings me to maps.  I made two sound like enough for this game, and it is.  How about 100 others in all parts of the world in real settings?  Almost all done with the same detail as the devs, but each has new ideas, killer layouts, different sizes, new start points with different field and equipment manifests, and all new crops, animals and functions not even found in the original game.  There are six regular and two root crops in the base game.  I think four animals if you count the chickens.  I've seen some of these maps with 14 crops and 8 animals types.  Then instead of 35 fields or so (you start with owning three), how about 80 and you start with 2 and less equipment?

Want even more play?  Play EVERY SINGLE MAP on one of three difficulty levels and start each game with lower resources, market buying and selling prices, and more difficult game dynamics.  I've got major time invested in a few games on my list and I can already tell this one is going straight to the top.  Just can't stop playing and discovering/learning new layers.  

Two shakin' thumbs up.

I have to say that being a farmer IRL there are a number of things that this game does not account for, including a number of my favorite activities. However i also should point out that if they built a game that did take everything into account then i doubt anybody would be able to fit it into their computers. My favorite aspect about this game is that i can drive tractors and harvesting equipment that i couldn't fit into my driveway or be able to afford in a million years in the real world. It is similar to 15 in many ways, but it has a lot more cool mods. Personally i recommend the International harvester pack.

The game is very similar to 'FS15', and sadly it looks to only have received a minor overhaul to the graphics. Many models and internal features are just copy pasted from the aforementioned game, which is quite disappointing.
Some other features have been improved, a little more realism has been added, (more dynamic soil, couple more crops types and plowing/fertilizing), and the game is an improvement over 'FS15', but I just don't feel that it were worth the 35€ pricetag. It just doesn't appear as if they actually did put all that much work into it. I would be satisfied with a price around 25€.

Edit: After clocking another 300 hours in this game since the review. I guess that I will still stick to what I felt back then. But clearly, also not a bad game to spent some time in from time to time, especially with friends. I haven't bought FS19, since I have plenty to still try here.

For the right player, this is the most addictive game ever made. With full freedom to set your own goals and work at your own pace, this game comes with endless possibilities. I personally enjoyed the discovery phase of figuring out how to work the land, load the tractors and implements, then make money and expand the farm. Driving tractors is so enjoyable and mastering logging was challenging but very rewarding when overcoming obstacles that can suddenly appear. 

The real downside of this game is the time investment. I have a fair bit of free time and use it playing this. You can hop in and out of a game but find that it will take hours and hours to reach even short term goals. Some days I can put 6+ hours without even trying - and loving it!

Honestly, I am really disappointed in this game.

I've never played farming simulator game before, but I kind of had good hopes due to all the postive reviews it recived.
However, the game was far from what I thought.

Most of the reviews are from returning players, who have played previous versions of this game. However, for me who just got into the game, the game was very unfriendly at introducing its mechanics.

It does have guides in game, however, I found they bombard me with bunch of keys that I am not even going to use often. Guides are too long, I do not need to be introduced to various fertilizer types by spraying it over and over, doing the same task that I will be doing once I get into actual game, but this is a guide. It could have been simplified by making me spray fertilizer once, and told me there are more fertilizers available. And often times, I just hire an worker because If I do it myself, it is going to take long and get boring, and the AI does better control of the equipment then me.

Then it just becomes a management game. literally watching the grass grow.


2 out of 10. Will not buy.
Ótimo jogo com amigos.

I own Farming Simulator 2011 and since I enjoyed it a lot back then, I thought buying a new version which is several generations ahead is a good idea.

Oh my god! What a disappointing experience!

Yes, this version has prettier graphics. But if you expect a graphics quality of 2016, you will be disappointed. This is especially true for the poor floor tiles. The textures of the fields are still poor. Especially harvested fields, plowed fields and sowed fields just look poor for 2016. I expected a lot more.

Vehicle driving physics are a desaster! Driving a car or driving a tractor still feels like 2011. You think you are driving an electric car, but without the torque. The gas-reaction is slow and the power curve is unrealistic. For a game that has been in development for another 5 years after 2011, and where driving is a central game element, I would expect that the developer put more focus on the driving physics and make it a more realistic experience. It's a simulation after all, right!?

Gameplay-wise there is nothing fundamentally new. You got more crops to seed, you get more animals to care for. You get more unloading stations to sell your products at, you get more vehicles. You get more of everything, but you get nothing fundamentally new. No new gameplay! It's basically all the same like in 2011.
Caring for animals isn't an improved gaming experience just because you have more of them and some now need more/other food etc..

I played on the standard map "Goldcrest Valley" if I remember correct. The starting location I think shall be the player's home / central place. However if you would like to get into livestock husbandry, you find the corresponding stables scattered all across the map. What is this? This is just annoying! From a business point of view, where efficiency is essential, you would like to centralize to keep supply ways as short as possible. The whole map design contradicts this.

If someone doesn't own a previous version of this game and likes to check it out, ok.
But for owners of a previous version, this one here offers nothing new.
I got it refunded.

I have 98 hours on record with farming simulator 15 and another 50 to 60 hours on farming simulator 17, so to kick things off it's pretty apparent I found something interesting in this series, but the mods are the only reason why I have as much time put in as I do. Both FS15 and FS17 are nicely polished to look at in my opinion, however having played flight simulators since I was a kid (20 years ago) I have always been more into realistic physics, interactive cockpits and the like rather than pretty graphics, and I think the FS series misses the mark on the realism element by a lot.

There is a lot of equipment to buy. Like I said above, everything is beautifully rendered and seems realistically animated from the outside anyway. Tractors sound decent with their turbos spooling up and diesel engines pinging away as they do and the interiors are rendered nicely, but it really bugs me that a game with the word "simulator" in it doesn't have functioning gauges and clickable buttons and levers in the cockpit. It's also a shame FS didn't take a page out of Euro Truck and American Truck Simulator and implement adjustable ergonomics (seats, mirrors, etc) while playing in the cockpit.

The physics of the equipment in this game is very unrealistic. Tire traction doesn't seem to be modeled in the vanilla game very accurately, the tractors and trailers don't feel wobbly or top-heavy as they would in real life, and the trademark big, bouncy tires that tractors have just ride flatly along all the different terrain in the game. The fact that one can drive right off a cliff and nothing happens to the equipment just seems wrong for a simulator. Getting back to the terrain, I would have expected a game from a genre with such a narrow field of features and mechanics to focus on would have done a better job of simulating soil mechanics such as deformation, moisture and nutrient levels, etc. That being said, keeping with the "all-show-no-go" theme, the mud that accumulates on the equipment looks good and can even be washed off if the player purchases a power washer.

As with pretty much everything else, the animals are rendered nicely and have decent animations, however I didn't find myself particularly interested in husbandry. I just didn't feel like there was enough to focus on with the animals. There's no way to directly interact with the animals, and that really kills things for me. There could have been a whole layer of bonding with one's animals while brushing them, scooping their poop, and whatever else that would have added depth and authenticity to the game.

My favorite part of the game is the forestry. Forestry seems to be where one can make what feels like a decent amount of money in a much shorter time than by working the fields, and it's novel to be able to fell trees and load them onto a trailer with a giant mechanical arm. I spent hours doing forestry while I hired the (rather dumb and buggy) AI to farm my fields. I enjoy how the trees cut differently depending on how the chainsaw is tilted, and I also like how the longer, straighter segments of wood will sell for more than pieces that in real life are not as valued, such as short, wavy pieces of wood that won't yield much product. This behooves the player to strategize about which tree they should cut down and how to subsequently cut the tree up.

All this being said, there is a massive modding community and many things that the vanilla game lacks can be rectified by using the appropriate mods such as a plethora of seasons mods from all sorts of parts of the world, a mod that attempts (to IMO a small degree of success) to improve the physics in the game, a mod that destroys grown crops when one's tires run them over, a saw dust mod that leaves a lovely looking pile of sawdust at the player's foot when they use the chainsaw, lots of different tractors to play with (even though as I said they all feel largely the same to one another), among a ton of other stuff. I never managed to find the realistic gearbox mod for FS17 that I loved so much on FS15, although I heard people talking about using it on forums.

In conclusion, I don't think the game engine is set up for truly simulation game play. The driving physics will never be as realistic as something like BeamNG.Drive or Spin Tires, the farming mechanics are rather basic to anyone who does a five minute search on Wikipedia about farming crops and what goes into it, and the animals are similarly simplistic. This game does however benefit massively from a steering wheel such as a G25 or G27. I would recommend this game to someone who enjoys a more forgiving, arcade-style game who has an interest in farming and likes things to looked polished, but doesn't want to sink a lot of time into a game with a steep learning curve and complex mechanics.

I tried so hard to like it...

TL;DR: Slow, repetitive, lacking clear objectives

I love the simulation/open world/building genre of games and this one looked right up my alley. I purchased 17 as the reviews were more favourable than the latest version.

The first thing I noticed were that the graphics were nowhere near as beautiful (good) as the trailers made out. But I can certainly forgive this, based on it being several years old.

I began by working my way through the tutorials, then jumped straight into the game. When in game, you continue to get hints which is great, as the tutorials only taught the basics. I was relieved to see that you can "hire" someone to do the repetitive work of driving up and down the fields. But you cannot avoid all boring work. A big portion of the game seems to be loading your trailer and driving into town or to other farms to sell your harvest. This can take a few minutes in real time. If you want to buy any equipment, you need to drive into town to pick it up, again taking several minutes.

One you've planted your seeds, you basically just have to wait. There is very little else to do other than visiting other farms, where you are offered "challenges" but these are usually as boring as spraying herbicides or plowing. You do at least earn money from them. I understand you can increase the speed at which time passes, but this would only mitigate so much.

Basically, the game-play is super slow and al though there is plenty to do and explore, it feels really repetitive. I kept giving it another chance and tried to like it, but I just could not really enjoy it.

Great game! Very addictive! But there comes a point when things become a grind (like most games). Mods really carry this game to the next level. I've found that for me personally, I have to set goals to keep my interest. Plowing, Cultivating, Fertilizing, Sowing, Harvesting, rince and repeat gets old fast. Its beyond me how anyone can play this game on hard with the amount of grind involved and how long it takes to save $$$. I play on easy, because honestly, I just don't have the time to invest. But, its awesome that the devs give you a choice on difficulty level.

That being said, any sand box type of game is really what  you make of it and Farming Sim 17 has the tools to do that, including the shear number of mods available.

Graphics are good and the game runs good on my potato of a computer. (GTX 970, AMD 9590, 16GB Ram)

Things that would make the game a bit more intuitive would be a search function on the in-game store page and in the mods section. The devs could also take note of some of the more, 'basic', type of mods and just make them standard in future iterations. Hiring workers is great, but they seem to have difficulty on fields that aren't fully square and or have trees and other objects too close to the headlands making turning around nye impossible for the AI or they get stuck. More thought could go into their map making on making sure to place objects far enough away to begin with. Although, I've had fun cutting down trees placed to close to fields.

Forestry/Logging is still the pain the *** that it was back in FS 15. Not sure why by now, Giants hasn't fleshed this out without players having to resort to mods, (not that all do).

As I said earlier, set goals in game. Working fields while fun at first, can get old. Buy animals (chickens, cows, pigs, sheep etc). Grow a variety of veggies/fruits. I've turned a couple of my fields into places I can put storage sheds, various types of tanks, garden centers etc. After the corny ingame music just about gets on your nerves, find a good youtube playlist of music instead, if you like jamming to tunes while you play.

This is a very chill game and if you feel rushed to get anything done, you're doing it wrong imo. For $20 its definitely worth a buy to melt some time away.

Update after 7 hours of play:
You thought baseball was boring?  Try sowing three fields!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1863551791
This is the view that lasts for at least a solid 30 minutes - maybe much longer.  If you suffer from migraine headaches this game may not be for you.

Oh in case you liked that other shot, here's another one going the other way:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1863553937

Grouchy:

After playing for my first 2 hours, this is mostly a driving simulator that involves farming equipment.  Yes you get to drive every inch of your field to harvest crop.  It's ungodly boring.  Then you have to figure out where to take your crop to sell it, and the game provides no clear explanation of how that all works.  Like for example, you can't sell wheat at the mill, because the mill ONLY accepts wheat from a train.  But the game doesn't explain this other than just showing the mill has train access.

Not convinced?  Wait there's more!!  You can PLOW TOO!  Every FREAKING INCH OF THE FIELD plow plow plow like there's no tomorrow!  Holy crap they'll let you fertilize it too!  I'm really not sure I can keep playing this without losing my marbles.

You know how RPGs are kind of dumb?  Where you just do the same things over and over again to level up and get new armor and weapons and spells?  There's not much problem solving involved most of the time, just hack and slash?  Yeah - this is exactly the same thing, but instead of armor and swords and spells its new tractors and a different crop and you can hire someone to help, but you're still going to do the majority of the work.  It's very grind-heavy.

But there is cow manure!!

I'm going to try to make it to the cow manure.  Then I will feel like I've accomplished the pinnacle of farming essence as much as I can in a game, without buying the farm!


Details:
You start with 3 fields, a truck, 3 tractors, a plowing attachment, a seeding attachment and a harvester.  These are all the most basic units.  2 of the fields are empty and 1 is ready to harvest.  There are hints on what to do next, if you can find them and figure out to run through them (don't try to click on them).

There are maybe 10-12 different crops you can plant and grow, along with animals such as chickens, sheep, pigs and cows.  All the animals need water, and some of them produce "slurry" that can be used as fertilizer.  Some of the crops can be sold in various markets and others are used as fertilizer.  Fertilizer is applied several times during the growth stages of the plants, and increase yield.  You start with a loan that collects interest.

You'll eventually find a store to buy and sell farm implements, including your pickup and tractors, and even garages.  You can buy seeds and livestock.  The strategy probably involves buying out fields before the competition does, which can only be done by maximizing profits to beat them to the best lots.


Positives:

What got me buying this in the first place - because I knew it was going to be pretty boring - was the exposure to all the implements of farming.  That's really pretty cool, because nowhere else will you find everything spelled out to this degree, unless you want to go to your local "Big R" farm supply store, but it's doubtful they could explain things to the degree this game does.  So this is really fantastic.

I'd recommend this if you like farming, or if you are really curious about agriculture with a tiny bit of economics thrown in.
