Just got the game on sale a few days ago.  Ive tried 2 older versions of the game ( 2011 & 2013 i beleive).  All and all ive no complaints.  It does get repetitive  but that is the nature of the job.  There are some things that have been added that take away from this though.  Logging is one.   

Once you figure out the basics its entertaining.  You finish the cycle from seed to sale with a few crops, look at the financials, and you can see a few places where you can improve your bottom line, this gives you some goals to work towards.  

Its a farming simulator and if you like that sort of thing, this game should scratch the itch.

There are a couple of things that would add greatly to this game in my opinion.

  The first is the need for tooltips.  There are so many symbols in the game that are not obvious to what they represent, it would be such a huge help to be able to hover over a symbol, and have a tooltip with an explanation of what it is.

The second addition would be to able to enter structures and be able to interact with the interior.  Maybe give us a bed so that we can speed thru time til the morning or something.

This game has been around for a long time now and its almost the exact same game now as it was in the beginning.  The core of the game has not changed.  Tooltips are as easy as anything to add, its just time, no real thinking.  A bunch of language files that get referenced to populate the popups properly.  The text exists already, just not anywhere handy.

The game already allows for enviromental interaction so being able to live in your farmhouse shouldnt be too big of deal either.  Make the houses prefabs and just let it be messed with like in Sykrim.

Making some new textures to represent a few new vehicles and pieces of equipment is not worth $30 dollars a year, for me at least.

Bottom line, decent game, 5 out of 10.  The devs figured out how to hook an audience 10-15 years ago and the game is pretty much the same as it was back in 2011.  A few new crops and logging.  Granted the do a great job with the vehicles and equipment, but looking at the latest model of some tractor is only going to go so far.

Buy it for $10 bucks, i wouldnt pay more.

Farming Simulator 17 offers a fun and relaxing view of life as a farmer.
While not as realistic as it wants to be, with its annoying physics engine and expensive DLC, it will still offer you a fun experience. The game lets you play with other people aross the globe, which is fun until the trolls come and ruin everything.

And then there's the mods. There's wacky crazy mods that lets you drive at insane speeds or fly, or mods that generally improve the game, like Seasons, Better Steering, MoreRealistic and the tons of vehicle and equipment mods. The mod support is a massive plus for this game.

Despite the positives, there are some negatives. The vehicle handling is not even close to realistic, and the DLC costs as much as the game, while offering a few tools compared to the 250 in the basegame.

Luckily this game was released when Giants cared enough to fix most bugs, making for a very stable game, and after the release of FS19, the game costs half as much.

+ Relaxing gameplay
+ Decent graphics
+ Runs well on most computers
+ Large selection of vehicles
+ Mod support

With Mods
+ Seasons
+ Realistic handling on most vehicles
+ Near endless amount of vehicles & maps

- Unrealistic physics engine
- Horrible steering
- Slow AI
- MP trolling
- Expensive DLC

Even after FS19 released, this is still a great farming simulation despite the inferior graphics and lack of John Deere, even better without the glitches and few mods.

8/10, recommended mods are Seasons, MoreRealistic, Follow Me & Better Steering.
If you're a fan of simulations, and are interested in farming this is definitley the best game for you out there (as well as fs19).
Relaxing, time-consuming and an unofficial requirement for German naturalisation process.

I've played every farm simulator except for 19 and I have to say this is my favorite. The graphics are excellent, the interface feels better, and the in-game radio is really a nice addition you don't realize until you turn it on. There is a pretty good variety of decent songs and you can even add your own into the game files if you like. The game removed some of the exploit gimmicks (e.g., resetting equipment back to your farm with no cost or penalty) and added vehicle aging increasing maintenance costs the older the equipment to make a downside for people who buy some placeables and leave the game on overnight. Cutting down and selling lumber still feels a bit wonky, but it's improved since the 15 game. I like the mission changes away from mowing grass and deliveries to being a worker on another's fields. It's nice to increase your reputation with field owners to reduce the costs of those fields.

If you're going to buy one of the farming simulators, I would definitely recommend this one.

It's meticulously detailed in its recreation of its machinery, the modding community is huge, and it has built in multiplayer. It's not perfect, but it's a good game to zone out to and just enjoy for a bit.

One of the most enjoyable games I've played in the past few years, I have closer to 200 hours of game time in offline play.

Really is a hidden masterpiece of the simulation genre. It hits the nice balance between the simulation and the game itself, giving you little milestones to produce that sense of achievement that real farmers would have to put a lot more hours in to get, (But they do actually get paid, so it balances out..).

If you're on the farmer's fence about this one, it will take time. A quick youtube video will tell you to sell all of your initial vehicles in person for the 20% increase in payout, withdraw a crippling loan (Not as bad as it sounds) and then reinvest all that money in less, but better equipment. A Panzer of a tractor, and some real neat equipment. I'm currently going for the maximum gain crop yield, which means ploughing the fields before sowing (That's planting seeds for those who are farming noobs like me.) but I now have to fertilise at all four stages of growth. Fortunately, the game has a helper system, where you can pay an extra pair of hands to do it for you. All you have to do is line them up with the field. 

I imagine this will be very important if I become a farm tycoon later on as you can buy many other fields and place logistical structures, but that process I'm doing will give me 100% more yield on top of what I would get with minimum effort. I'll definitely be doing it until I can pick up my second and third tractors. 

All in all, this game is very well priced at this current time, as I've spent a few hours in it already and I haven't even started logging, or animal farming.

I like this game.  The graphics are good.  I have FS2009 and FS2013 and you can see the improvements that have been made in graphics and playability from those games.  I am 900 hours in and still play  now and again.  Minor annoyances are that animals can be a long way from your home farm for feeding, watering etc.  You may also have to drive a long way to sell crops, animals.  It is hard to complete fertilising and spraying missions on  other farms when crops are visible as you can't  easily see what you have already done.  Harvesting grown crops for others is easier.  You will need to do these help missions at the start to be able to buy new improved tractors, harvesters etc.  Cheap old equipment is easily available from modders though.  The game is not for thrill seekers - like real farming it takes time to get somewhere but the game can be speeded up a lot so that you don't have to wait for crops to grow.  You can adjust many items such as growth, withering, fertiliser required in the game settings.   Sometimes equipment can get stuck but can be reset easily.  I do not play multiplayer so cannot comment on this.  I have also got Real Farm (buggy mess) and Pure Farm (better -can go to other countries) but FS is the king.

Okay, so I'm slightly obsessed with this game right now. My dad was a farmer before we littles were born and he's always telling us lovely nostalgic stories about his life out in the fresh air.

Personally, I think fresh air is overrated but this game makes it a lot easier to visualise and understand what my dad's on about. You get to drive cool machinery without getting dirty. You get to see something of the life of a modern-day farmer. And it's a great way to spend time without demanding too much thinking.

My only complaint is that, besides the graphics being a bit weird (distances tend to get these odd neon-green strips), the keyboard controls are RIDICULOUS. It took me days just to figure out how to operate everything and even now, I still have to check the interrinets for help. The tutorials are vague, so be prepared to tab between the game and your internet browser for help.

All that said, I'm enjoying it now I've got the hang of it. Although I still can't drive straight to save my life...

Never played games like this. Then the steam sales came, I had too much € on my account from selling dota items, too much alcohol resulted in buying this game.
After sitting in my library for more than a month without being played, I thought, let's give it a try. And I must say, I have not played any other games anymore since that moment haha
I have worked myself on a big farm from my 16th till 21st, so I had some nostalgic feelings with a lot of stuff in this game.
But, now I can't get away anymore from it.
Sound is good, Graphics are good to very good. Mechanics are easy to learn and I love the "relaxing" gameplay.
Before you know it, you are busy sowing, cultvating and making more and more to feed your farm animals

now the negative things, and I must say, that I play without mods, so some of these things may be solved by using mods.
The helpers, not the smartest AI in the game, if your fields are too close too eachother, it may happen you are cultivating fields, that were almost ready to be harvested. 
The no damage, you can crash, jump, spin and hit other traffic, without any damage. Makes the game "less" realistic tbh
the limeted space at shops when you are buying.
When you want to buy pallets with seeds, food or fertilizer, you can't buy it in bulk, always pallet by pallet and not be able to load several pallets in big sowing machines or sprayers. Or even in silo's to store and use later.
THe lack of maps, when you only play vanilla.

But even with the above mentionned negative features, I love the game, it is relaxing after long day at work.
Now I am off, I need to feed my cows!

A good bit of fun I suppose.  It's neat for a while, but it quickly grows tedious.  It's definitely a chill out and drive up and down a field for an hour kind of game.  It doesn't explain much and it could use some polish, and despite enjoying it for a short while with a friend, I can't really recommend it.

I may not have hundreds of hours invested at this point, but i have enough time to get a pretty well off little farm going. I'm not a tractor fanatic, i aint a truck enthusiast, i've never worked with animals a day in my life. But in Farming simulator 17 i'm a bonefied farmboy and after a genuinely tiring day in the office (in real life), I love coming home and getting straight to work on my farm! Its strangely theraputic, relaxing, and frustrating at the same time when you miss spots to plow or harvest, but all in a days work ay??

I will sit for hours and get lost in maintaining my fields, chopping trees, caring for animals, selling items, debating wether to buy that £520,000 tractor and a 12m wide plow. Is it worth it? DAMN RIGHT ITS WORTH IT. I bought this game on a whim, along side dark souls 3. And as ive gotten older, sure, occasionally you like to challenge yourself with games, which is what dark souls 3 is, but sometimes you just want to relax, listn to music, and do whatever you want without a care in the world. 

You can toggle Farm Sim to be as easy or as hard as you like. Want your crops to grow well but cant be assed maintaining them? turn off the need to fertilise. Want crops to grow really fast? set your time to 120x normal. Want to just sit and watch the sun go down over the hills? Set it to real time and relax. 

Personally, cant recommend Farming simulator 17 enough. I ALWAYS tell my friends to 'give it a chance' and even my non-gaming girlfriend has a great wee farm of her own with chickens and cows and loves tending to her farm. 5 stars.

I'm heavily disapointed that the wood logging system and bailing and such work so poorly.  Go to pickup a log and it chucks it or drops it.  Many of the attachemnts for things are useless like the log jaws for pretty much anything vehicle.  They either don't grip tight enough or drop logs with a firm grip. Back to logging...  chips...  both of the mobile chip makers suck.  I have no idea how they expected you to load the one with the crane and the one that has no crane will eat your logs if there isn't a trailer under the conveyor.  It's supposed to have a 5k storage, but it will stop there and eat your logs with no return.  2 full grown trees will make 50k~ chips  but for all that effort and extra equipment you can just load the logs onto the log trailer and sell them at the sawmill pond easier.

Ok. First of all, the game does do a decent job of simulating being a farmer, game mechanics-wise, but nothing ever CHANGES. You'll always get a good harvest, your animals are always healthy. More on that at the end. That aside, here's my experiance.
 So the thing that really stands out to me about this game is its repetitiveness. Basically, the goal of the game is to grind money to be able to buy things that help the repetitive tasks go faster, but that doesn't really change the experiance, the repetiveness.

For example, you start out with, well, bad and tiny everything. The tools are the width of the tractor, so cultivating, sowing, and harvesting each take 15 minuets at least on the smallest starter field, 40 on the biggest starter field. You just do the same thing: up and down the field to cultivate, or plow, it. Up and down it again to sow seeds in it. Up and down yet again, after a long wait- even if I turn time and growth rates to the fastest- to harvest it. Then you gotta repeat the process over and over again- cultivate, sow, harvest, cultivate, sow, harvest- forever. Then you just go buy bigger tools so that you can get it over with faster, and tools that cultivate and sow at the same time, to, again, get it over with faster.

And note that farm helpers are worthless as they drain your money fast and you AFK for just a few minuets, then you come back to see they have ran themselves into a tree and stopped work, or they have cultivated/sown/harvested only one row and then have stopped work, or have done the job but left big swaths of unworked land inbetween the rows of cultivated/sown/harvested land.

The tutorials really really suck too, I had to watch video tutorials and gameplay videos to figure out what I needed to do to, say, refill my seed sower, or what I needed to get and know to be able to take care of animals.

Once I realised this-the repetiveness of crops-, I thought, well, the crops part of this game sucks, so let's try animals! Well, there's no option to start an animal-focused game, you have to start on the crops path. So I grinded and grinded until I could buy the needed tools to care for sheep. I got four sheep to start off with. So I watered them, then mowed a grass field I planted, then collected the grass shavings to feed the sheep with.

So that was OK, but it was still really repetitive, and every animal exept sheep force you to grow yet more crops, often expensive ones that require their own special equipment, to get their productivity to 100 percent. Collect water from the river, mow, collect the shavings, feed them the shavings, take their wool to the spinnery to sell it, then repeat.

I am OK with repetitive games. My favorite game is the Isle, my second favorite American Truck Simulator. But Farming Simulator is differant because, like I mentioned before, nothing ever changes. Nothing. Sure, sometimes it's cloudy weather, but your animals never get sick and die, they don't die if you don't water/feed them. Your crops will never have a ruined or bad harvest, your tractor never breaks down, nothing changes. 

To compare this with American Truck Simulator, you never know what will happen, will some car crash into you? Will it start to spontaneously rain hard and you will slip? Do you have enough service time to make it to your destination? Will sleeping make me late? Do you have enough gas? Which job pays the best? Can I fit on that dirt road, or through that construction zone? *Will* there be a construction zone? Will I get stuck in traffic? And I can think of more questions of things that may change your trip.

But in Farming Simulator, you just don't have anything to pay attention to like that. No, you just drive a tractor up and down a field, grinding. No, you just get water, collect food for your animals. No, you just endlessly repeat the same tasks, trying to grind for the equipment to get it done faster! But it's still the same tasks, endlessly repeating no matter how fast you get a task done, you'll just have to do it again, and again!
 I also found it really unsatysfying because you just do the same things on the same field endlessly.



Well, that's pretty much all I have to say about this game. So, thank you so much for reading to the end! Please rate my review, and feel free to comment. I am responsive to questions, suggestions and whatever else.

Even though very similar to last Farming Simulator, improvements have been made. I think there is enough new content to make it worth buying.

Pros:
+Lots of new machines.
+New game mechanics, and improvements to old ones.
+Trains are now driveable, and you can transport goods with them.
+You can now rent machines, it helps making money.
+You can modify machines, for example, change their color.
+Pigs.
+There is cheaper machines for forestry now.

Cons:
-Most of the physics aren't very good.

I can't think of much cons, but that doesn't mean there aren't more. Overall, this game is great, and one of the most enjoyable simulators I know.

I Insanly recommend this if you want something casual to pass the time, im not a farmer myself and even I find this incredibly fun. Though the new game 'Farming Simulator 19' being 2x as good as this i still highly, highly recommend this game to all types of gamers.

Been a Farming Sim series fan since 2009 and still enjoying it to this day. It's fun and relaxing to play with friends in Multiplayer, work hard to make more money, buy better and more powerful equipment or take care of cows, sheep and pigs. Although, no matter how much I like this game, there are many flaws to be fixed and features that can and should be added/improved:

-Physics (handling of bales/pallets; masses of equipment; etc.)
-Graphics (addition of Motion Blur, Depth of Field and Ambient Occlusion effects; shaders to be reworked; rain to have impact on textures; dirt mapping to be more real life-like; entire environment textures reworked and colored properly to have more realistic appearance; etc.)
-Gameplay (full seasons cycle; more difficulty options for players seeking maximum realism; horse power and mass to have impact on implements/trailers used; adjusted pricing of animals, equipment and placeables; separately purchasable biogas plant, animal farms, forests; addition of dynamic terrain and vegetation (highly requested); improved Multiplayer synchronization; etc.)
-Equipment and Animals (more youngtimer equipment that would be suitable for smaller to medium sized farms (highly requested); more animals to be added to the game (beef cattle, broilers, turkeys, goats and more); chickens to be purchasable (this was available in FS 13 and 15) and feedable; etc.)

There's a truckload and more things to be mentioned, but that's enough for now.

My personal score for this Farming Sim would be a strong 9 out of 10, developers put a lot of effort into production of this game, became more open with the modding community and also gave modders an opportunity to participate in contests and create official and fully licensed DLC's.

For the next FS I hope to see some new changes and additions, something that was never seen before in any Farming Simulator game.

I'm a big Farming Simulator fan. Been playing FS13 since it was released. Spent around 500 hours on it. I bought FS15, but never had time to play a lot (just played around 4-5 hours). Now I have time to play and so far I'm loving this game.

The FS series has improved a whole lot since I last played. I wanted to wait until FS19 comes out, but this was on sale for only 8€ so I bought it to have some fun until FS19 comes out. 

What I love about this game is that it's both so close and so far from reality. It gives you the freedom to do whatever the heck you want. You can just be a casual farmer or grow your farm and make money from everything. I remember when on FS13 I created a career just to farm sheep. I wanted to see how far could I go. And turns out sheep are quite profitable.

If you still haven't bought this, what are you waiting for?

I played 15 for about 65 hours so I have a basis for comparison, if a limited one. I was very skeptical about getting this as I was afraid that it would be just 15 with the number 17. I waited and waited for it to go on sale. Finally it dropped to 50% off and I picked it up. It feels so different. Granted it's the same game but there are many noticable improvements. I am lazy and it's late so I'll leave it up to you to do the research on the differences but it is well worth the price of admission. It's a vastly improved game and the easy access to mods makes it even better. Pick this one up over 15 if you don't have either. Get this if you do have 15 and want a much better game.

Someone described Farm Sim 17 being the proper evolultion of the prior two generations, and I fully agree - the fields and equipment match nicely, foresty works well, there are many new great features that used to be available only as mods, the availble equipment is nicer, and it all feels right. Granted, I think most people had modded FS15 into whatever they wanted it to be, but this seems right from the start. Beyond adding a few trucks and maybe some other bits I don't feel that there is any point to adding to what is already there. I also really like that there aren't empty fields, they are all owned by AI farmers, and instead of running around doing delivery for cash early in the game now you can work the AI farmer's fields for cash. Overall a great experience and a big enough improvement to justify spending money on.

Update: Having just played Farm Sim 19 for a short period, this is the game I'd want to play. The overall feel and finish of the product is so much better. Don't waste your money like I did on the "all new and improved" title....

In the past, Giants didn't improve Farming Sim franchice much over the versions. You just got nicer graphics, slightly different UI, few more trees in maps, but basically that was it. It was literally same manure in different package. FS15, although introducing forestry and much better graphics, was really big dissapointment. I have to admit that i didn't had high hopes for this FS17 game at all. On top of that, all the hype Giants did didn't help it at all. Their first released CGI trailer was almost like ridiculing gamers, and when they added 10€ for the price, I felt that this would be just another money grab.

I'm glad I was wrong!

This game have better graphics, of course, but also improved physics and few improved or added game mechanics. This time there are pigs and you won't just feed your cows and get milk. You need to clean the feeding area too and over time they breed and you get more cattle. I would loved to be able to get in the cowhouse and to manually clean the bedding too to get manure, but maybe next time. Another thing improved are trailers. In previous titles you couldn't use your trailers for nothing else than what they were made for, to carry crops OR to carry logs. You couldn't do both. This time, if you want, you can carry crops AND firewood, or pallets or even smaller tools with your trailers and you wont need separate trailers for that! And you can even carry smaller stuff with your hands.

This time, this is a working simulator. Previous titles were more like farming game, only mods made it farming simulator.

I'm not going to add all the same details other reviewers have said in thousands of reviews. I just say, if you are interested of good farming simulator but are unsure which one you should get, go check out few Youtube lets play videos and then get this. Do not bother with previous titles.

After you have bought this, from Giants main site you can get previous FS15 DLC packs upgraded for FS17 for free. There are also couple of other nice mods you certainly need and which will improve your experience. Go get them!

10/10 Strongly recommended!

(I will update this review as new content like DLC's and mods come out)

**Updated November 18 2018**

Farming Simulator 17 is out and I got about 320 hours in the game so far. 
Time for my Review/opinion of the game:

**DLC:
I personally love the new DLC's and I find the pricing to be just about right. Maybe a little steep for some of them, but it's (or maybe) necessary for a company to survive in this constant flow of games?
I'm not going to go into details about the DLC's other than they to add various amounts of new content to the game.
There's also Add-Ons from other companies you can purchase to add more content to the game. (I really like the Straw Add-On from Aerosoft).

General:
At first, FS17 felt like an incremental update to FS15. The gameplay is mostly the same, the controls, the menus and so on. There are of course graphical differences to the menus and they look nice and fresh. The controls can be better tweaked and there are a lot more settings to play around with to get the best personal experience for you.
After 270 hours I have come to understand that this version of the "simulator" is more, much, much more than just an incremental update. 
The menus give you a better overview of the various prices, livestock, fields etc. The map is a lot bigger and you actually have to plan ahead before you drive off to get your new tool/equipment at the store which adds to the realism. The same goes for delivering goods on the other side of the map. Is it worth driving all the way over there, or should I wait for the prices to climb a little more somewhere else?
-
In FS15 I had about 250 mods(!) 50 of which was "essential" and have now been added to the core game. The other 200 or so mods are sure to come to FS17 in due time thanks to the awesome modding community!

**Mods:
Mods, ah, glorious mods! The mods add A TON of new content and tweaks to the game. As of November 18 2018 the mod sites are bursting with both low and high-quality mods. For the most part, the mods are great and of high quality. I have 265 / 7.3 GB of mods running on my (modded) map as of right now and I can't see me playing without any of them. Well, maybe a few are non-essentials ;-)
I'm not judging FS17 based on the mods, but I have to say that a game that you have the option to mod, and that has integrated the modding well deserves a notion. Having said that, you DO NOT NEED to mod FS17 to be able to enjoy the game, there are hundreds of hours of fun without mods!

**Bugs:
Bugfixing is a big part of the "upkeep" of any game, and Giants are reasonably good at fixing.
Most of the bugs this game had on release are gone (a few linger on).
-
So far I'm overall happy with the game and all the new stuff like animals, crops, vehicles, and tools. But, there's always room for improvement so I'm listing them below;

Positive:
- New and fresh feel to the game / "simulator".
- New vehicles, tools, equipment, crops, animals.
- Vehicle handling and sounds are much better.
- Vehicle Customization.
- Better animal handling (they don't magically pop up on the pasture).
- Nice big map.
- Graphics and lighting are much improved.
- Texture and particle systems are also much improved.
- Missions! Actual missions to help your fellow farmers.
- Plowing/tilling the land finally makes a difference.
- Fertilizing up to 3 times finally makes a difference.
- Live radio streaming.
- So many small and big details have been fixed.

Neutral:
- Trains? Maybe they will come in handy (I only have 30 hours in the game so far). And I guess it's a little about how you choose to play.
- Still no ground deformation. I would have loved to see this in the game.
- Sunset/sunrise is still fixed in one location, no East or West...
**Still, after 320 hours have not had the use of trains.

Negative:
- Vehicle handling feels a bit "jerky" at low speeds, it's not as "smooth" as it used to be when trying to precision load a pallet etc.
- No preview when customizing vehicles.
- No Damage (I can drive off a cliff and keep driving).
- Still feels more like an arcade game than a simulator (but a lot of the mods usually fixes that to some extent).
- Rain still clips trough buildings (so there is no sense in parking them indoors). **There's a mod for that. I mean, the rain still clips through the roof, but you can add a "dirty" rain mod.

Recommended: YES!
Rating: 8/10.
**Rating (as of November 18 2018): 9/10

Grew up on a 7 acre farm and always wondered what it'd be like to farm and expand from there.
The Farming Simulator series by giants software has always been the go-to farming game.
There's a good variety of crops in this game and it'll run with pretty low hardware specs, however if you're going to use a lot of mods i'd recommend you have a pretty solid gaming rig.
And when you mod this game you can get pretty close to real farming for a game. The seasons mod ads some serious realism and is worth checking out. There's also excellent built in modding within the game's mod hub.

I first want to say that I think unless someone has 100 hours or more on a game they shouldnt be allowed to place a review. My honest opinion of FS 17 is good. It has a fair tutorial  could use improvement(but what game dosent). Its interface with the steam controler is good however not to many templates use the gyro to steer. I had to make one. Graphics are very good to good a little jerky at times. Getting used to days being growing seasons takes a bit of getting used to(but is very minor) Plowing is hinky at best but improves with GPS mod or Courseplay. More attention needs to be made to mega farms such as the farms in the United states not all of us want hobbie farms and yes bigger is better. Animals seem to be an after thought real pigs have litters of 8 to 16 not one at a time 50 cows dont have just 1 calf a season. Sheep usualy have twins and more than 1 a season also Chickens multiply worse than rabbits if you let them sit. Some farmers like to grow animals some like to grow crops. A lot like to do both when theres reward in it (money) The animal part of this game falls short at best.  The farming crops side of this game is very good although the selling part sucks when you sell a truckload of grain in real life the price does not go down while you dump you get paid the begining price for the whole load. In  game you lose while you unload this part was not thought out well. All in all this is a good game, it is fun to play. You can find loads of maps and mods. Most of the big maps suck! But there are pople out there who take pride in modding and there maps are great because they test and retest before publishing you have to sort the lemmons out like anything else. More thought needs to be made on function (dose it work flawlessly) in this game than pretty (A tractor can be dog crap ugly but if it works very well its valuable) and they will have a home run in the sim community. This game is very good for the money but falls just short of great.

Countless hours on console and PC. It is one of the most relaxing games out there. And on top of that Giants are a great company. They truly care about their fan base. I would recommend the FS series to anyone.

I've been playing the FS series ever since 2011 came out, and I gotta say they keeping adding new content that brings me back everytime. 2011 had some ugh... less than ideal mechanics that got fixed in the very next game. 2017 however adds so much in the way of quality of life, and everything from the core mechanics to the UI is much more refined and smooth. The introduction of Ai support for mowers and sprayers, although I think sprayer AI support were added in FS 15, is a nice upgrade from the previous games. The AI is much better than it used to be, way better, although it does have some quirks. They will get stuck on hydro poles or slight inclines depending how the equipment moves in a turn, but all-in-all it's much better than it used to be. New crops, new ways to fertilize fields, new equipment, new storage techniques, the introduction of a dedicated mod hub built into the game itself. All these things are why I keep coming back to this game, and really Farming Sim is just a game that you can sit down and play for hours. Losing track of time is probably the easiest thing to do once you start playing.

Fs 19 is coming soon so I thought I'd finally do a review.  I've been playing the FS games since 09 and the one thing I can say.  Thank whatever forces that are out there finally paying attention are now creating farming games so I don't have to play this trash any more.  The name should be "Farming Equipment Arcade".  The farming side is a joke and always has been.  The physics are meh at best the AI is something other than that because there is no intelligence involved.  Over the years fans have put in requests and been ignored over and over again.  Once "Cattle and Crops" is released I will never look back.  
1. FS 09 = Pig.
2. FS 11 = Same pig with lipstick.
3. FS 13 = Same pig with lipstick add wig.
4. FS 15 = Same pig with lipstick and wig add blush.
5. FS 17 = Same pig with lipstick, wig, and blush. Comb wig.
6. FS 19 = Same pig with lipstick, combed wig, and blush add high heals.

Although I have to give it to Giants.  Great business model.  Do just about nothing and let the modders who want a real game do all the work for you while you sit around collecting the checks.

I expected this game to be a farm simulator, but it only appears to simulate large farms and is more tailored towards larger equipment.  My expection was to be able to simulate my small farm so that I might improve my processes.

I have only finished the tutorials and there was nothing stellar leaned from the experience.  I farm hay and processes are missing easily two major steps, cutting and raking, or one dependent on your equipment.  None of my tractors have auto equipment hook-ups, so all I can say it must be nice.

The comment that old equipment is misleading, but that is fine with me.  Please don't hesitate to emphasize, so I can continue to buy low hour equipment at a cheap price.  With respect to hours before maintenance, it would be more appropriate to see a table of  start times and interval hours.  Pick-up trucks normal go by miles or kilometers.  My truck is 24 years old and doesn't have an hour meter.  My wife's truck is fairly new and doesn't have an hour meter.  

Keyboard steering worked fine for the tutorials, but as soon as you start a career driving a truck becomes problematic.  So, I downloaded the keyboard steering mod and am now tring to work through over acceleration issues.  The control issues are very time consuming as the ability to escape back into options to make changes doesn't appear to be available.  You have to back out of the career make the change then start all over again.  

If you are an American, you find out that everything is metric and in Euros vs. dollars.  The forum comments regarding the matter are interesting, but don't address the fact game that the game is not globalized and lacks sophistication.  I can work in both systems, but this is a game and should accomodate all customers.  I did not see this point  advertised.  Guess I should have sifted through the forum comments before purchasing.  I have visited and lived in Europe; likewise, Asia.  I didn't buy this game to play in competition.  I bought this game to relax, so I don't need the extra steps.

edit #2: i figured out how to fix the above problem. I disabled the framerate limiter upon launch. this is what was causing the issue. The game does not act the way it should at 144 HZ. I can no longer support FS17 with a thumbs up anymore. I can't enjoy the game because it deletes my savefiles and progress each time I start the game up for a few hours of relaxing me-time. I just don't feel like starting from scratch each time that I boot the game.
I've googled for a solution, but somehow it seems I'm the only person in the world that experiences this problem. I can see that the game is awesome, I love the idea, but I just can't get to the good stuff because each time I have to restart and each time I have to harvest my beginner field, cultivate them, seed them and do a few missions. But then I return for another session and discover that I have to do it allover again.
I want to play FS17, not Groundhog Day Simulator '17. That's really all there's to it.
Not recommended from me.

Edit:
After researching some more and making my google-search as stupid and spelling-error heavy as I could, I found some references to this problem with idiot-level solutions that didn't work.
I did find a way to finnagle a back-up that the game makes of the savefiles into something workable, so there's a work around and I can keep on playing my savefile. Still, that doesn't mean that I'm going to change my recommendation into a thumbs-up because I did find out that Giant was made aware of this problem quite early after this game went gold and Giant didn't fix the problem. A problem, mind you, that I learned exists in all the Farming Simulator games!
So there you have it. DLC that you can buy, but no fixes for persistent problems that carry over from iteration to iteration? If Giant wants a thumbs-up for that, they can suck it. It's not going to happen.

I have no idea why I wasted so much time on this game last year. I guess I got caught up in exploring the world to figure out what other crazy thing you can do. I felt like firing it up again the other day, and after a couple hours I noticed just how tedious the core gameplay is.

This is definitely a matter of taste, I will admit. But I was looking for interesting and complex management elements, hell maybe even a goal or two, not just a vehicle simulator. I wasn't raised on a farm and I don't get a hard-on for tractors or any other vehicle for that matter. The pacing is the very definition of boring. Half of my game time was spent leaving the game open while taking a nap. Farm Simulator can be used as an alternative to Valium.

There is no management challenge here to speak of. Just plant, fertilize, wait, fertilize, wait, fertilize, wait, harvest and repeat. At high difficulty, the only way to make any progress is to just do a bunch of the side-tasks. Get a chainsaw and cut down trees to sell. Fertilize the fields of one of the many NPCs. Collect eggs and gold nuggets...

What I'm saying is, the optimal way to play the game is to ignore the fundamental mechanics.... i.e., the farming part of farm simulator. The fastest way to advance is to mow grass. I shit you not: the most profitable activity you can do as a farmer is mow grass, stamp the living shit out of it with your tractor for a half hour, and then after a bunch of waiting, selling the silage to your friendly neighborhood biofuels plant. Now that's sad. And probably realistic, too. I guess it's my fault for playing on "realistic" difficulty.

Overall, this game is a vehicle and log physics simulator while at the same time being a heaping pile of unintentional social commentary regarding the broken economics of farming in real life.

This game destroyed my free time.

I used to think farming simulators were nothing but a big cash grab in the simulator games. You see the fast development of many simulator games that are developed across the world just to make some fast cash. They usually are full of bugs with severely broken languages due to way over use of Google translate. 

This is NOT one of those games. 

This is a great game. This is a classic. And a an all time favorite. 

The Farming Simulator franchise is a very successful series of games focused solely on becoming a farmer. 

You can find their games on mobile devices as well and they are just as good. I am a huge fan of the mobile version of these games because they are so identical to the pc versions. 

The game is simple. Farm. 

You start with very little. A few plots and some basic equipment. You can choose to take out some loans to help get you some better things but you really gotta get farming. 

Get in that tractor and start clearing away that field. Plant your seed... Lol... Then move on to the next. Get everything planted and speed up time to watch the fields grow. 

Time to start collecting your crops. Be sure to use a good size tipper to collect as much as possible to help limit how many times you need to empty out. 

The game also includes animals such as pigs, cows, and sheep. They come in handy for some extra cash as well as fertilizer for your plants. 

If you wanted to more than one thing at once, you can use AI helpers to get more work done. Plow a field, collect your crops, they can help! Unfortunately they cannot sell your merchandise... This is something the mobile versions offer though. 

One of the coolest features of the games is the mod work provided by the fans. You can find custom maps, tractors and equipment. Even some custom scripts for special occasions. It's pretty cool this is offered and has such popularity 

And if you want to work on your farm with a friend, the game offers multiplayer support! 

Overall... These farming games are wonderful. They are detailed, look beautiful, and offer plenty of fun. If you like tycoon simulator games, this is for you. Much fun for you!!!! 

Can't wait for the next one in the series.

I don't care that there are 30 kind of different tractors, the gameplay is just blatantly boring. You basically drive a tractor over a field 90% of the time or let the AI do it for you (so why play the game at all?). There's even a "mission", where you have to drive over a field several real life hours straight without the ability to save progress. 

The UI and Tutorials do a horrendous job, to get you in the game.

Also economically uninteresting. You start off with almost everything needed. Would be cooler with a Harvest Moon vibe, like starting off with a small shed and upgrading after each big harvest. This game be like: Silos? TRAINS?! ANIMALS?!? We got you, bro.

You might just say "But wait! It's a simualtor!" So tell me then when did a farmer invent instant teleportation and can switch from one vehicle to another, which are kilometers apart, in an instant?

You will be better off with Stardew Valley and helping your local real life farmer out (not sure if he let's you drive his tractor though).

I was curious about this game for years and finally took the plunge since it was on sale. It was well worth the ten dollars. There's a lot of things to do epecially if you add mods. You can play the game several different ways. If you're the kind of person that likes to grind to get better equipment and nicer stuff, the vanilla game is perfect for you. Each and every upgrade will feel extremely rewarding because you worked for it. If you're the type that wants the best equipment quickly, you can do that too by building up enough money to buy things like solar panels which earn income and require no maintanence. To get money quickly you can exploit the game by speeding up time and buying more solar panels from the income until you eventually can buy wind turbines which make lots of money. You could literally turn your farm into a wind farm and be a billionaire and buy everything you want and do it rather quickly. It's certainly not challenging and the sense of reward will be gone, but the option is there for people who just want to buy and collect everything. You can also try to find 100 hidden gold nuggets which is fun and challenging and has a huge monetary payback. This feels much more rewarding because it takes time and work. You can raise animals which can become very involved but is quite fun if you like to keep busy. You must grow or buy ingredients for their feed, mix their feed, give them bedding, clean their mess and use it for fertilizer or sell it, breed them, etc. You can log forests and if you download the mods you can eventually sell furniture. Or you can just farm your own fields if you like. There is even a map with a quarry that makes concrete and other items as a download. You can download excellent modded maps like Pinecove which has tons of room to expand by placing buildings you purchase. You can produce your own silage in several different ways. There are mods that have antique tractors and farming equipment and maps of old farms you can start on if you want to go old school. There are also giant maps with industry. You can buy property and you can lower the prices of these properties by doing missions. You can do farming missions for other NPC farmers for money using their equipment and make good money. You can store your fruits and grains in silos and wait until demand is high and increase your profit.  Some mods completely change the game "Gifts of the Caucacus" mod has  an airplane you can hire to fertilize your fields while you ride along, A quarry, shops where you can drop off your material and get other material which in turn leads to making items you can sell elsewhere. On this map in order to do forestry you must do a quest involving finding the missing forestry equipment hidden all over the map. On this map you can also purchase factories and shops from a realtor if you raise your reputation and have a lot of cash. Tons of stuff to do! There are sonme drawbacks. Doing missions for other farmers actually pays more than raising your own crops. So if you're only in it for the money, it  spoils the game a bit. You still get a lot of satisfaction of going through all the stages of growing a final product if you farm for yourself, but all that work isn't going to make you the most money. If you're just in it to get the reward of managing a successful farm than the lucrative issues shouldn't be a problem. just do them if you need cash quickly. Maintenance fees are also somewhat of a chore as you'll find yourself selling old equipment because it costs too much too maintain. You can overcome this by purchasing things like solar panels or turbines  to effectively cancel the hassle and even cut a profit. There are small maps and large maps. There are in game mods and third party mods and all of them are easy to install if you've ever modded before or just Youtube them for instructions if you're not mod savvy. This game is a relaxing kind of game. It's a stress reliever....unless you're trying to manage 300 cows, sheep, and pigs....lol!
It’s a great sort of game to play if you just want to zone out but it can get pretty boring, I would only get this game if it’s got a discount otherwise just give it a pass
its a really good game

TLDR: Not a full game so dont pay full price.  This game is still in beta as it does not have a storyline.

The good:
You want to use tractors, plows, seeders, fertilizer, slurry tanks, and balers?  This game has that.  The mechanics of farming are done pretty well.  Though dont expect to use fungacides/pesticides as they arent in the game.  Lots of tractors and equipment.  In short, if you want to farm you can farm.

The bad:
No old tractors.  No seasons.  You must download a 3rd party mod to get either of these things.  "Missions" are you work for another farmer, thats it.  Cant change liters to gallons.  Crop yield isnt measured in bushels, only liters.  Tractors/equipment cost more everyday you them in maintenance fees even if you dont use them.  Game starts out at 5 times normal speed.  Cant create new animals pens, so if you want sheep/pigs/coes, there is a predetermined single spot on the map for each animal and that is it.

The ugly:
No storyline. No objectives.   After a while theres no point.  If you can imagine Skyrim with all the game mechanics minus the story, thats what this game is.  Would it really have been so hard to create a story that started with you inheriting your grand dads old farm, equipment, and bank debt that was due by a certain time or you lost the farm?

Even More ugly:
You make more money working for other farmers than if you sold the same crop on the same land yourself.  Much more.  To top it all off, you are using their equipment.  There is no point in buying land or even different tractors in the game due to this.  There is zero challenge nor is there a sense of accomplishment when buying your own equipment.

Conclusions:
The game is worth the $10 US I paid on sale.  You will have a bit of fun farming so I will still recommend the game...  but only if it is on sale.  It will not be worth more until the game devs create a story(s) and fix the all of the ugly things wrong with this game.

A very good and complete farming experience with amazing game mechanics, decent physics and rewarding gameplay. 
However; as the game progressed, I started to get pretty annoyed with the counter-intuitive interfaces and some of the controller settings. (And being a pilot, I'm used to complex interfaces) 

So I thought - based on the music, choppy english translation and square unimaginative interfaces- I'll bet a ball to a cent that this game was developed by a German company... turns out it was.
So, once the game developers take some trips abroad and broaden their horizons outside of their own German Game Developer University, they will definitely become a serious competitor in their branch. The same can be said for the musicians and translators of the game; They're amazingly skilled, but unfortunately they lack the feeling.

Highly and warmly recommended, with amazing potential for the people behind the game- if they're willing to think outside the box and less by the books.

Edit: I realize the negatives outweigh the positives in this review, even though it's important feedback.
My Compliments to the team behind the game and the intense work and research they have put into it. Good Job!

Like others said, this game is not what I expected.  It really is a tractor-driving sim, not a farming sim.  There was no real depth to the game, the physics are just plain silly, and even the “helper” AI is unreliable.  I never felt like I was working toward anything or actually managing a farm.  They start you out with three fields, three tractors, and even two trains.  Trains!  Actual trains that you own.  What beginner farmer owns his/her own TRAINS??  My point is, they start you out with way too many resources, so you never really feel like you’re starting from scratch, and anything you would work for is just to do more of the same tractor driving.

Even little things like not being penalized/fined for anything bothered me.  Driving through a neighbor’s field, knocking over stop signs, or hitting cars had no effect or consequences on the world. If I lease a piece of equipment and bang it up, I would expect to be charged.  Not the case with this game.  I could even block traffic with my trains, or cut down and log all of the trees on someone else’s property with no consequences.  These seem like weird things to complain about, but they are just examples of how nothing had meaning in this game, and it really takes away the immersion.  I should have to worry about safety and logistics of transporting goods if I’m managing my own farm. 

Now I know the game can’t get super in-depth or complex or it wouldn’t be any fun.  For example, I know fertilizer was simplified to just one generic “fertilizer” to make it easy, and that’s fine.  But the entire game was overly-simplified to the point of not being a simulation.

I wouldn’t recommend this game.

At first I was a bit gutted that the graphics were the same, but with all the extra vehicles and tools and gameplay, I soon wasn't worrying about it. With the ability to add dozens of mods, the gameplay is enhanced even more. I would however like to see more attention to detail, for instance: better ambience, vehicle/tool sounds being more raw, a difference between internal and external sounds. I guess i'll have to wait and see what FS19 brings! I'm sure I wont stop playing this until FS19 comes out in November though. One of the best simulators I've played since ETS2.

Even though 17 is very authentic and very well researched, it still falls short of delivering a truly realistic sim. The town is still lacking in life. The well designed buildings show reflections of the outside instead of letting people see inside and this is a big letdown. The car store is roomy without any soul and the people walking around show no spirit and no human activities  are performed anywhere. The cars are a nice touch, but they just drive around without stopping.

The farms themselves though, are top notch and give a truly amazing setting. The South American Rancha is especially stunning and offers a credible view of how wealthy farmers would live, both on the inside and on the outside. The farming equippment is as endearing as ever and more educational than ever. Buy this if you don't mind the rather dreamscape like land of this world and if you want to know what farming is all about.

The game also taught me a lot about farming and modern equipment in general. Highly recommended if you like farming, driving and operating farming equipment.

I.Can't.Stop.Farming. 

Seriously, the game is quite addictive, but to be fair, I find myself hooked on farming games like Stardew Valley or Harvest Moon when I play them as well. There's just something fun about playing through repetitive crop cycles. 

FS17 at its core is pretty relaxed right from the get go. Albeit also a bit confusing...You'll kick off your campaign mode with a lightweight tutorial, and then bam...you're on your own. Throughout the town you'll find some additional contextual tutorials for various things which works great, but really it's up to you how to play. 

I quickly learned tending my own 4 starter fields was a bit slow, so I went ahead and worked for everyone else gaining money quickly to upgrade my own tractors and equipment significantly faster. At that point, hiring my assistants to do the majority of the work for me, turning it more of the game into a light management sim. 

Honestly, it's just a relaxing game, but it's mega repetitive if you just do the basics (drive up a row and back down another, repeat thousands of times). 

I personally haven't tapped into the massive mod community yet either, but i'm feeling the itch to see what's available (and seeing recommendations from other reviewers has piqued my interests.)

So it's a great game, and a pretty legit sim i'm guessing. Not mega robust, but the mod community seems to have the intricacies covered from what i'm hearing. Totally recommend hopping into a tractor and giving this a shot!

Competent enough with modding but fails big with paid dedicated servers.

In the plentiful realm of "german-everything-simulators", the ones with the old MS Flight Simulator fonts, this is not a bad game. It has it's quirks, it's very basic compared to other sims or games in 2017, but does a good enough job. Where it really shines is with the mods, those increase the number of vehicles, maps and realism, if you want more, that is.

The number of mods in game is sufficient but you might want to search some sites around for some niche ones. In-game mod download speeds are laughable too.

The big downside in this game, the one that makes this a negative review, are paid dedicated servers. You either rent a server from a number of providers or have to buy another copy of the game to host a dedicated server. Note that this doesn't mean you can't host a game. In this day and age, a developer or publisher treating customers in this manner, with such greed, can not be excused.

Graphics, gameplay, music, sound are nothing to write home about, but for now the competition is weaker than this franchise. That might change in the future, but right now this is still the best farming simulation out there... unfortunately.

Let's start by saying this is a fun game.  So that is a big plus.  But, as far as the multiplayer mechanics go, this game is TERRIBLE!  The first thing you notice when playing multiplayer is that there is ALOT of syncing, I mean ALOT.  Every time a player joins,  Instead of the player syncing with the server,  the server syncs to the new player.  Atleast it seams that way.  So everytime a player joins your game freezes for 5> seconds.  Sometimes these syncs seem to take up to a minute.  The next point I want to make is the number of "Trolls" in this game.  The lack of Server support by the developers has made it impossible to secure any public server.  Of course you can ban the players, but from what I understand is somehow the file doesnt save when either restarting or reseting the server.  So once you reset all those banned players can come right back in a wreck havok on your server.  One of the biggest flaws is that trolls log onto the server and move all the vehicles into the water and now you cannot play on that server until an admin gets on to reset the machinery.  If the developers of this game want to have a successful lasunch to FS19, YOU MUST DO SOMETHING ABOUT THE MULTIPLAYER COMMUNITY!   Give the server owners a more tools to keep there server safe and enjoyable.  You need to also do something about the syncing.  It is rediculous the amount of time you pause to sync to another player joining.

I really enjoyed Farming Simulator 17, after having played a fair amount of 15, and being introduced to the franchise with 2013.

They made a lot of improvements and enhancements, making the game a much more immersive and interesting experience.

Unfortunately, the multiplayer aspect is still sorely lacking in current technological capability, by still suffering from the design choice to freeze all players for a brief period whenever a new player joins the game. Lack of multiplayer server administration functionality means the game is also not well suited to public game communities, but rather a small number of friends.

Still, it is the best farming simulator out there, and is a worthwhile purchase if you enjoy the concept of various types of arable farming with machinery and a little bit of animal husbandry, especially in single player.

The modding community is quite good despite the game still not having steam workshop support, with the developer making efforts in this version to integrate mods directly into the game and their web site.

The DLC are overpriced for the content and rarely go on sale beyond minor discounts compared to most games out there, but still enjoyable if you don't mind that aspect.

Farming Sim is a great game and I would recommend this to anyone who is into realisic games. The models for all vehicles and placeable objects are well designed and very detailed. Also the in-game settings are very useful. It covers everything from fuel consumption, to plant growth, to volume levels and even to whether you want there to be cars on the road.

What also makes this game so good is the ability to easily mod it. Mods for this game are easily obtained and easy to add. Also, because a lot of the game settings are stored in xml files, it is easy to alter a map, a vehicle, or placeable. This can be useful as you can give yourself as much money as you want (if you are wanting a map just to experiment with) or if you want to change how much a tipper, a bucket or a tanker can hold.

Just because you can do this, you don't have to and you can just play the game as it is. This is what makes it great for players who are looking for realism or players who are not to interested in realism and just want to play to see how crazy you can get it.

However, a small glitch I have noticed is the height your character is at can randomly change. While this may not sound to major, it means you sometimes can't cut down a tree lower than you usually would and sometimes it stops you going though doorways. Though this could just be caused by a mod creating an error, rather than the game itself.

Need to wind down after a hard days work? This is the game for you. Just sit back and relax. Nobody is trying to kill you and you are not trying to kill anyone.  It's just you, your animals, tractors, and awesome equipment that you had no idea existed.  I have learned an awful lot about the agriculture busniness. Just because of this game I was searching google for how farmers do this in real life and to my surprise the equipement, precision, and science is immence. This game does have a large learning curve and it does not hold your hand. You are free to do whatever you want with little to no consequences.  Now here's the thing.  99% of the player base do not play vanilla. They're using community created mods and maps.  The FS community has created brilliant mods that can make the game more realistic and challenging if you so wish or plough with the same tractor your grandpa had when you were a kid. Oh the nastalga and memories. GIANTS has made a game that people can easily get into, but that's where it falls short. It's not a simulator and it is not realistic at all.

VANILLA FARMING SIMULATOR 17

No Seasons
No Breakdowns or Repairs
No Damage Simulations
No Bankruptcy - infinite negative bank balance
No weeds
No crop destruction if you drive through a germinating field.
No pests
No animal diseases or deaths
No Drought
No Floods
Straw, Hay, and Grass do not rot
Fields are flat.
Perfect Square fields
Tracters drive like they're on asphalt. Even in a bumpy muddy and ploughed field.
Your tires don't even get dirty like they should.
Terrible AI that only works in a straight line, which is why the fields are either square or rectangular.
Crappy phyiscs engine, which makes manual pallet and bale work tedious.
You're the ghost in the town and people don't notice you
Traffic gets in your way and won't move. They just honk their horn in anger. So you save, exit, reload your save and turn traffic off. The annoyance is gone. Now it's a ghost town.

MODDED FARMING SIMULATOR 17

Seasons Mod - Spring, Summer, Autumn, Winter - You must plan and develope your farm to prepare for the coming seasons, weather forcast, and animals, which will die if you don't take care of them.  Geological weather data. Perform regular maintanence on your vehichles or inpede a high penalty cost. Snow, rain, hail and crops will die if planted in the wrong seasons and they won't even germinate if the soil tempture is too low.

GPS Mod - Sophisticated GPS System, which the real modern tractors have. The tractor will lock the front wheels to the coordinates of the hud. It's a really good option to use if you want to do a neat and tidy job yourself.

CoursePlay 5 - AI actually works in all field shapes. Not just squares and rectangles. You can completely automate your farm when it becomes too large for a one man team. There's even a handy manual online.

AutoCombine - Similar to courseplay, but only works for field work. Courseplay is better.

Crop Destruction - you can no longer drive though your crops without destorying them.

Ground Response - Your tractor is no longer driving on asphalt, but a ploughed bumpy field.

Drive Control - Oh? Your tractor is slipping now because of the ground response? Use this for 4WD and differential locks.

Tire Dirt - Your tires actually get dirty in the field.

ProSeed - Creates tram lines, which prevents your tires from destorying the crop and it works well with crop destruction mod and you can even turn off 1/2 of the seeder to make sure the tram lines are perfectly placed down withthe same width of your fertlizer spreader or sprayor, just like they do in real life.

Tons of high quality tractors to choose from. 
- FS15 No Fendt. MODS Fendt's galore. John Deere.
- FS17 Fendt. MODS John Deere. I especially love the R7 mod by TM. I seem to recall a tweet from GIANTS about acquiring the rights for John Deere tractors for FS19.

The physics eh? Hard to put pallets and bales on your trailer? It's the engines fault. Install the mod that improves it, albeit only marginally, or just use a trailer with an Autoload script that will put all the bales and pallets perfectly stacked and alligned on the trailer for you. 1 hour job done in seconds!

Add more crop types. Apple orchard, oranges, cherries etc. 

Most importantly. Waaaaaayy better maps!! Sandy Bay17, Chellington, The West Coast, Churn! Challenging terrain and field shapes. Bah just try and use GIANTS AI with those fields.

Add more animals. - which reminds me
- FS15 Chickens, Sheep, Cows ---> MOD Pigs and slaughter houses.
- FS17 Chickens, Sheep, Cows, Pigs. Sell your cows and pigs ---> MOD Horses
- Confirmed FS19 Chickens, Sheep, Cows, Pigs, Horses ---> MOD Pikachu?  I'd like to care for a pikachu.

You can go on Youtube for tutorials on these mods. It's very easy.

GIANTS is outsourcing talent from across the world and paying the mod authors for every download their mod gets.  Your mod will only be entered into the ModHub after it passes the lengthy testing phase by GIANTS and it must be rated 4 stars or more by the user base in order to get paid.  Soybeans and Sugarcane? You could add those crops, tools, and equipment to harvest it before with a mod in FS15 and now its here officially in 17. This is what GIANTS and other big name software companies, like Bethesda, are doing.  Since the mod community does their job for them? There is next to no innovation each release to GIANTS Editor and their game engine since 2007. What kind of improvements should we expect for FS19?

"High Dynamic Range Rendering allows us to display the complete spectrum of colors at the same time, the added Bloom will make light irradiation much more realistic, thanks to SSAO all objects in the game now cast their own shadows, which will be realistically cast thanks to the new Light Scattering technique. The sun on the new dynamic sky now serves as a light source and the clouds, which are now voxel-based 3D objects, reflect the light absolutely realistically."

 Oh. Eye candy and fluff. HDR, which is a 1984 technique they can do on their lunch break and SSAO, which was developed in 2007 by Crytek. Litterly nothing we have seen before, but it is an improvement to their engine. It really shows how behind and old their engine is in a niche market. I'm tired of the 2D field textures, since 2007, that try real hard to look 3D. I'll be waiting till a mod author comes up with that idea.

This game has everything for every type of player. I myself play more on the realism side and add all the realistic enhancing mods like Seasons, which changes the base game drastically to the point it's not the same game anymore that GIANTS envisioned. Remember that when you read these reviews and keep downloading these mods to support the mod authors.
Best game out there

I can't honestly say that i've ever felt a burning desire to plough fields, plant crops, take care of herds of animals, and spray sh*t everywhere, but I CAN confirm that it's a strangely relaxing experience.

I'm only 4 hours in, and i've barely scratched the surface. But the one thing that is already apparent with this title, is that it does exactly what ETS2 and ATS do to me: It takes away my ability to decide how long I play it for. My last session was meant to be an hour, and it quickly became three.

You don't sit down with the intention of spending all day/night on it, but be warned, the game takes what it wants from you. Don't believe me? Buy the game and tell me how long it takes you to cancel those not-so-important-after-all family plans because you have crops to harvest. That planned weekend away with your other half? Forget it. You have pigs to feed and new land to buy. And that job interview you had booked for next week? Not happening. Stocking up your grain silos and cleaning your tractor ready for the next day's work will be far more important to you. This game has the potential to destroy friendships and relationships!

On a serious note, I have deliberately delayed buying this game since it's release. Fact is, I never intended to buy it at all. "Ploughing fields and cleaning up animal waste. Who could be addicted to such a game?" I thought. "Sounds boring!"

**spends around 900hrs hauling different loads from city to city in ETS2 and ATS**

Who am I to call it boring?

Recently i've been thinking more and more about buying it, so I added it to my wishlist about 6 weeks ago. This morning, I took the plunge and bought it. Worth it? Ohhh yessss!!

It turns out I had massively underestimated this game. Truthfully, I only decided to buy it on the recommendation of a family member who's been playing it for some time. But I finally understand what all the hype is about. I get why there are so many raving reviews.

This title has so much to offer. It's not just about driving tractors and harvesting crops. There's a whole economy to manage too, workers to hire, money to make, and new vehicles and equipment to buy and sell. Furthermore, there's a whole plethora of mods available!

The graphics are beautiful and the sounds are awesome, from the birds singing in the trees, to machinery clunking away in the background. The environment has been well thought out, and there's plenty to keep you busy. Like any great game, it's all too easy to loose track of time as you become totally immersed.

There is a lot of stuff to get used to, so don't expect to be making a success of things when you first get started. I highly recommend going through the tutorials! These will be of huge benefit to you when you start the career mode, as you'll quickly discover that you don't start out with all of the equipment that you really need, so you have to either budget for new equipment or make the best of what you DO have for the time being.

The sheer number of controls and functions is a real mindbender, but it all adds to the experience. I did find that the default controls setup was a bit clumsy and frustrating, so I spent a lot of time remapping them to work with my aging Logitech G25. I believe this title can also be played in VR, which is great news to me as an Oculus owner! I haven't tried it yet though. The TrackIR seems to be doing the job well enough on it's own for the time being. Another useful tool in my opinion, since you often need to be looking both ahead and behind your vehicle while working with some of the equipment.

If you have a wheel/pedals, you WILL want to use them with this game. I can't see the likes of an Xbox controller offering anywhere near the level of functionality and fingertip control that you really need. I know people are getting by just fine with a gamepad, but if you have a controller which offers far more buttons and axes, use it.

This review is one of MANY which can't recommend the game enough. No review will ever do the game justice.

Speaking of reviews, I'm writing this during a coffee break, and I have a field that needs my attention!

Buy it! You won't be disappointed!

This game can seem overwhelming at first to someone who has never played a Farming Sim before, and knows nothing about farming. It is challenging to the newcomer like me, but if you invest in the tutorials and help menus, you will learn as you go and enjoy it. However, I am very addicted so far and I will list below why:

Side note: There are some tutorials out there on how to make tons of money right off the bat with the game. Usually it involves selling everything you own, maxing out your loan, and installing solar panels, then leaving your system on for 3 solid real time days......I recommend not doing that, as IF you follow the basics of the game, such as farming multiple crop types, fertilizing, and only selling harvests when prices are high, you will make plenty of money and it will be YOUR hard earned work and rewards, not an exploit. 

Here's what I like about the game:
- Multiple ways to make money, farming numerous types of crop, harvesting lumber, working other farmers fields for really good pay, installing money generating placeables on your farm, etc.
 
- Very technical game with attention to detail and the graphics and modelling matches that. If you do not like simulation games or have some hatred of farmers, then you won't like this game.

- Steep learning curve but not overwhelming, just follow the tutorials and help menus, and work your way up to new crops and new machines.

- The financial system is fairly simple yet robust, and really does well to make you feel like YOU OWN each piece of equipment with your hard work and savings. You have a list of various buyers for your crops, that list is color coded to prices (demand) that are bad, neutral, good, and really good (high demand). You can borrow up to $300K in loans, which do not have any time limit to pay them back, but you are charged interest each day until you do. 

-This game runs VERY well even on full graphics. The graphics are very good, and the game runs super smooth even though I have an older gaming PC. 

- I have not yet found any glitches or bugs, again it runs smooth. 

- A LOT of control over your difficulty. You can choose Easy Medium or Hard as usual, but you get further control over, how often you have to fertilize crops, whether or not your crops whither and so on. This tweaking really lets you play to your play style and skill level (aka, I'm a noob).

- There's a lot more to do than "just farming" you can purchase forklifts, logging equipment, semi-trucks/trailers, and A TON more. This game is packed with A LOT of really cool vehicles that make your life easier and give you variety in what to do.  

- I like that you can hire AI helpers (good AI with a few hiccups) to take over various time consuming tasks while you do other stuff. Using them properly is the absolute key to success when farming by yourself in a time efficient manner. 

- You have hands on control of your farming output from start to finish. I love the fact that you decide what crops go in what field, you put work into increasing the yield of those crops, harvesting those crops, storing those crops in your silos, and eventually loading up those crops into a trailer and hauling them with your pickup to sell to a vendor. From start to finish you get to be involved in it all, or have AI workers help where needed. 

- MOD SUPPORT!

- You get hundreds of hours of game-play from a game that costs $35 full retail. 

Things I don't like:
- The more your vehicles/equipment age, the more they cost per day to keep, I feel this happens a bit too fast. This is deducted from you at midnight of each day, going into the thousands per day or more. There is no way to remedy this other than selling off the old rig (for next to nothing) and purchasing a new one (which could be A LOT of money). This really cuts into your bottom dollar, but is also realistic in managing your overall farm. So it's a positive if you like realism, but a steep learning curve for new players.

- The store, which you purchase all of your equipment and supplies, is REALLY far from your farm, making trips there to pick up a new header for your combine (which travels 14 MPH) a real chore. I would have liked to see this store closer. You can however purchase trailers and such to transport pallets of fertilizer and seeds that you buy, and that's fun. You can fast travel to this store by your self (no vehicle with you), but if you need a vehicle to pick up your purchase, you have to drive that vehicle over there and back again, which sucks if it goes 14 mph....

- The controls on the faster vehicles such as your pickup, are quite unrealistic and if you're going fast, it's really easy to spin out. However it is manageable and once you get the hang of it it's not a big deal. 

Overall, this game is really fun, I recommend it to anyone who is open minded about their games, who likes technical/simulation games, or who enjoys management type games where you have a lot of investment into what you own in the game and how well your business does. I feel that Farming Simulator 2017 does this very well, it makes you put stock into the game and feel like you have ownership over your success and the things you own.

Great graphics and very relaxing to play. If your a fan of simulators, farming, animal husbandry, or even hauling cargo, then I would say this game is a definite buy. Enjoy!

I could never understand what drew me to this game. I refused to pull the trigger for many years, through many versions of the game, and many sale-events. I did so because there is no logical reason I should want to play this game. I had a very good understanding of what the game entailed, and exactly what it was, and felt like I shouldn't want this game. I understood the game; what I did not understand was myself. Why did I keep looking at it each time it came up on my queue? Why did I always find myself one moment away from hitting buy?

I spent more time watching trailers, reviews and videos on this franchise over the last few years than I have so far played the game. Always I told myself that some aspect of our shared evolution over the millenia, from hunter gatherers to the people we are today, was the root cause of my fascination in a game that had no bullets, no fights, no mysteries or storylines. I finally gave in to my more basic nature, I succumb to the pressure passed into my genome by my anscestors and i purchased the game. 

I do not regret it. I so far love this game. I wish I knew what drove me to buy it, why I could never look away from it, but it does not matter. I love harvesting fields and sowing them. Thank you to whoever is responsible for this game.
