I can't lie to you. I'm just not capable of giving an unbiased review.

If you look at my play times for each game in the series going back to FS2009, you'll notice that I have 1000s of hours invested in them. I just couldn't possibly give a negative review based on this very fact alone.

Are the games, including FS2017, perfect? No, of course not. We all have things we'd like to see changed or added to the games, but that would be an impossible undertaking by the designers at Giants Software.

In any case, what really makes these games amazing? The community of modders. Many players create top quality maps, equipment, and even complete redesigns of the game by adding countless new crops, animals, production, and manufacturing possibilities that surpass the base game.

I've played most of the farming simulator type games available, and for me, the Giants FS series can't be beat at the moment. They have been the King of farming simulators for quite a few years. I also have a hard time picking just one of Giants FS games because they each are different, as in each offer something not available in the other games.

TLDR: It's a great farming simulator title, and has a large mod community that keeps the game enjoyable, even after 1000s of hours if you so incline to do.

10/10 easy

Instead of taking down waves of baddies, how about hopping in a tractor and ploughing a field for a couple of hours? It might not be as exotic as space travel, but it’s still a form of escapism (unless you happen to be a farmer), and Farming Simulator 17 looks to bring you the best wheat growing/sheep dipping/manure spreading experience available.

Farming Simulator 17 is a slow burn. Don’t jump into it expecting to get to grips with the game straight away, there is a lot to learn. From crop management to animal husbandry, this game is dense. There are a few tutorials that can be selected from the start, but if you’re new to the series, you’re bound to be a bit daunted. Even something as simple digging up a field requires a decent level of understanding of how tractors and their attachments work.

Having said that, you’ve got the time to learn it all, because Farming Simulator 17 is a leisurely game. Unless you play it on the hardest difficulty, where crops deteriorate if you don’t harvest them in time, you can go at your own pace, and have the freedom to do whatever you want. The game almost becomes zen-like when you take on a job. It’s not uncommon to have to spend 40 minutes harvesting crops in a field. That’s 40 real time minutes of going backwards and forwards across the same few hectares, just driving your tractor and turning around when you get to the end. Whether or not that appeals is key to what you’ll get out of the game, because while there are plenty of different activities, they all get repetitive after a short time. There’s also a basketball court in town if you fancy shooting some hoops, something we all know farmers are famous for.

Graphically it’s inoffensive, but you’d struggle to call it pretty. It’s the best looking Farming Simulator title yet, but honestly that was a low bar to start with. It introduces some new features to the series, such as being able to play as a female character, and there are new crops to tackle too. If you’re getting hot under the collar about the prospect of growing your own field of soya beans, then you already know that this is a game for you.

Over a 1000 hours spent on this, many of them making my Broxton map,  and I've now spent a couple of hundred hours farming it. 
People might be inclined to mock players of this game, for some reason it might draw the same kind of ridicule as a train sim (nothing wrong with them either). But I don't care about that - It's a great fun game/arcade sim with plenty to do, and loads of mods - tractors and implements of all ages and maps to suit all tastes. 
I worked on a farm in the Broxton area many years ago, and this game really takes me back to the feel of real farming. The graphic models of Giants' tractors and all equipment are superb, so mods are not essential, but the many mods on offer definitely add to the game.
The default game is a bit simplified, so it can appeal to all ages, but still it is good enough to feel like some real farming, and if you want more realism, there are plenty of third party mods that increase the realism, Seasons being the first one that comes to mind.
If you're tired of/not a fan of fast paced shooters, and want a more relaxed challenge, then this is a great change of pace.
Recommended.

Buy the best equipment in the game and you'll have to spend 40 hours of your play time removing trees. Such a time sink. I do like the idea that we can still put in passive income items. I never have to worry about money, want a new combine harvester, I'll buy it. Want to invest in some cows or pigs, I'll buy it. I know it's slightly unrealistic for a farmer to have millions sitting in the bank, but I don't care. The day they remove passive income items from the game is the day I'll stop playing. All in all 4 out of 5 stars.

I have 2189 hours in farming simulator 15. I was very worried that 17 would be too much like 15. I can tell you honestly after 6 hours playing 17 the improvements are well worth it. The minute you load the game and start playing you can tell how different things are. Many of the script mods are now part of the game. Most of my favorite tractor mods are part of the game. I find that when Giants make a tractor it is generally more polished. The field textures are better than any of the modded textures I've found so far. The improvements to the feel of driving equipment are great. One aspect of the game that really shocked me is the improvements in sound. They have also managed to improve the quality and performance of the graphics at the same time. The game performs flawlessly with all graphics settings on max at 4k resolution with every nvidia option set to highest quality. The level of configurability is another great feature of this new version. I can honestly say it feels like a completely new game and as someone who really liked 15 with all the improvements in 17 I will probably not be able to play 15 anymore.

400+ hours and counting in FS 15, less than 60 in FS17 and don't give a damn about it.

Why the difference? Because FS 17 is a near carbon copy of 15, the AI is actually worse, the differences are trivial and the mechanics are arbitrary and stupid. Don't get me wrong, it's not that the game isn't fun. It's that it barely qualifies as a different game from 15. It even shares a map from 15, giving the player only ONE new map in the base game, for a grand total of two maps. If you want more than that you have to buy the platinum expansion for a whopping one more. This could've just as easily been an expansion pack for FS15 as a new game.

It's also not a simulator by any stretch of the imagination. It's one gigantic, arcadey, interactive commercial for the agricultural equipment industry and nothing more.

It has only one thing over FS15: The modding scene seems to be a little better, and that's a good thing because the FS15 modding scene is a wasteland of broken or cheated garbage.

Great game and surprisingly addictive, really helps to make you appreciate what goes into farming. There are loads of different things to do, and loads of kit to buy which makes the initial learning curve fairly steep but utube will help.

When it comes to gameplay, there are some jobs that you have to do yourself but the normal crop based jobs (cultivating, sowing, fertilizing and harvesting) can be delegated to AI workers which means you don't have to drive up and down the fields if you don't want to. If like me, you like business sims then it's great not having to always do those jobs. 

One minor criticism I have, on normal difficulty there is a prefectly legitimate way to make tons of money very easily which seems a little bit unrealistic. Personally once I found out about it I decided not to use it, and it may not be possible on hard difficulty but you can use it or not depending on your preference I guess.

Overall I'm really enjoying it and would recommend to any who likes the idea.
Gets better every year, makes you feel as if you really are a farmer in your day job.

Fix the game engine to support tracks and skid steers correctly :(  Also still waiting for an asian map. I used to laugh at the people who played Farming Sim (and Truck Sim and that ilk) and then Farming Simulator was on sale on Google Play at 10p so I bought the game and tried it out and I enjoyed it so much I went and bought FS17.

I have to say that the gameplay itself isn't really captivating and can feel a little tedious at times (especially on the hardest difficulty where it can be a bit of a grind). I most of the time multi-task so I'll be watching TV or a film whilst playing this game but I think the thing that keeps me engaged is the financial aspect. 

It's mainly building up my finances and buying bigger more powerful machines and increasing my efficiency or investing in forrestry or animal husbandry that keeps working the same fields over and over worthy of my time.

Whilst there are some quirks with the game (e.g. graphics and some of the mechanics like pallet forks) overall it's very comprehensive and it feels to me (a layman) that it has captured all the aspects a farmer might encounter and for that reason I feel it's more simulator than game.

And as always the work of the dedicated modding community elevates the status and playability of the title and the sandbox nature of the game also gives the freedom to try out mods that have nothing or everything to do with farming.

Definitely reccommend to those who don't need a game to be constantly stimulating and don't recommend for those who can't handle relaxing quiet gameplay.

Farming Sumulator 2017, what can I say?

Pro's
[list]
    [*] Multiplayer support is offered in game or via the purchase of dedicated servers
    [*] Of all the Farming Simulator's it has the greatest variety of vehicles
    [*] Very strong modding community which produce great mods for the game
[/list]

Con's:
[list]
    [*] Outdated game engine when released, especially when compared to Farming Simulator 2015
    [*] Attention to detail - raining inside, no seasons, ground physics when wet, etc
    [*] Weak DLC's compared to Farming Simulator 2015- KUHN Pack DLC is the only one worth purchasing
[/list]

I think that the game is awsome. Yes you do start with the boring jobs and nothing to do. However as the farm expands you have not enough time to do everything.  

+ Forestry
+ Detailed vehicles
+ Price changes in economy of the game
+ Discounts in shop in the game
+ Over 250 brands and vehicles  
+ Huge Map
+ Official Expansions and DLC (Some for free as well)
+ Not many glitches or bugs (I only found 1 or 2)
- Game is abandoned after around 1-2 years since release
- Not balanced gameplay (E.g. you earn a lot for things you don't work much for and the opposite you don't earn a lot for things you have to put a lot of work into.)
- No ground physics
- No sun on the skybox

Overall I think that if you are into simulators you would like the game.

I really like this game. Here's a list of pros and cons.
Pros:
Very good graphics
Pretty good texture quality 
Even on a Mac running a VM (Virtual Machine) ran decently smooth on lowest settings
Will run on a computer with a potato for a graphics card
Very easy and safe to install mods
Will be fun for lots of people (Depending on your point of veiw)
Very addicting
Cons:
AI is one of my least favorite AI's ever next to an iPad game. Texture quality on them is fine, but, if you hit them, you will expeirience one of the most unrealistic crash ever. It doesn't have crash physics, but, still, when you hit them, you A.) Stop dead in your tracks B.) Go flying or C.) Drive right over them and flip.
Will not autosave
Can have random spikes of lag (on intense graphics)
Acceleration and braking is unrealistic
Can get frustrating if you've had long day and it crashes.

All in all, it is a very good game and is worth your money in my opinion. Hope you find this helpful and have a good day/week/year/decade/century/milenia/eon/life.

[538 hrs on record, in 4 months, vs FS15 being 280 in two years]

Let me start off by setting the tone.

I've played since FS11 and despite the radical inclusion of forestry in FS15, which I enjoyed very much, I was still very bitter towards GIANTS and their progress from 11 to 15. I felt their added features lacking, their improvements lacking and overall vision or direction absent. Their DLCs quite often were obvious money grabs, rather than any real addition to a player's farming strategy. 

Odds are, they were a small but up and coming software development team which accomplished what they could, considering they were also creating smaller versions of the game for the Android and iOS platforms. Maybe they were spread too thin.

This year, they release FS17 with a $45 price tag, up from $29 in the past and I couldn't help but facepalm myself. I sarcastically thought, "Let me guess, we'll have MORE TRACTORS" as a way to justify the new cost.

24 literal gameplay hours into it, and I have to say, it has caught up to most of my expectations. Kudos for bringing this game up to speed and making it almost worth the $45. It's about time. 

The game mechanics haven't changed a whole lot. It seems like midway through FS15, before they fleshed out all the bugs, they cloned it and started making FS17. This would explain a lot of the bugs that were resolved late in FS15 showing up in FS17. Currently, the "jitter bug" prevents me from doing forestry unless I use autoload trailer mods. 

So what's the deal?

Missions have changed. Previously we had delivery and mowing missions. I didn't mind the delivery ones, but they were sorta boring. The mowing missions I enjoyed. They're now gone, which I don't think is right. They should come back and with more variety. 

Now, we have missions where we are maintaining other farmer's fields. Thing is, you can't hire anyone to do it. You have to do it yourself. I would prefer to be able to hire, even if it meant it would cut into my profit.

There are a few more crops, 1 more live stock (pigs), chickens haven't changed and lots of tractors. There are even two useless trains. Well, useless on the Goldcrest Valley map. Two little loops around the center of the map. Regardless, it will make for great maps by the modders. Goldcrest Valley is an awful map. How is it that modders make better maps?

Despite my gripes... I'm really addicted to this game.

And with the $45 price tag and $19 DLCs... they'd better be making a phenomenal FS2019.

Bought this as a reward for myself after I did well on my finals. I played FS15 and loved it, but the small quirks got me frustrated and I stopped playing. I don't see that happening with FS17. I've only had it for 2 months and I already have 92 hours at the time of writing this. It fixes most of the issues I had with FS15 and adds so much more, it looks great and is the greatest way to relax after a busy day at the office I can think of.

There I was, smack-dab in the middle of the Maplefield town square at midnight, searching for that one elusive nugget of gold. By studying the map I’d already deduced that my prize was resting on top of a lawyer’s office, but I had no idea how to access the roof as climbing nearby trash cans and awnings proved utterly fruitless. Finally I managed to reach the top of the building by scurrying up a nearby flagpole and making a desperate leap of faith, thereby securing my precious golden quarry. Satisfied with my accomplishments for the evening, I retreated to the nearby park to shoot some hoops.

If all of this sounds far-fetched for a game that calls itself Farming Simulator 17, please, read on.

The fact is that Giants Software’s latest agricultural undertaking is equal parts straight-faced management sim and delirious open-world petri dish. If you choose to ignore the latter and focus only on the serious aspect of the farming business, this option is definitely there for you. But you’re also missing out on some of the wonderfully quirky charms this game has to offer.

Let’s discuss the farming first, as it is obviously the core of the Farming Simulator 17 experience. As a burgeoning farm owner, it is your initial responsibility to cultivate, sow, fertilize and harvest your fields on a routine basis. You sell your goods for profit and the cycle begins anew. From there, things become much more complicated. The amount of tasks initially thrown your way — not to mention choosing the appropriate equipment to complete these tasks — can be daunting at first. Thankfully there are adequate in-game tutorials that should be completed before proceeding further in the game, especially if you don’t know seed from slurry. Once you settle into your rural groove and find your way around, there comes that delightfully satisfying rhythm that only the best of management sims can provide. More than any other game in the genre, FS 17 provides a peaceful, zen-like aspect that constantly propels you to keep playing. Make no mistake: If you’ve ever considered playing a farm sim, this is the one you’ll want to play.

New to FS 17 is mod support for consoles, which lends a whole new level of value and replayability. New vehicles, new equipment, and even entirely new maps are available, and while the console mods are no match for what's available on PC, it’s still an incredible boon for XB1 and PS4 players. If you find yourself tiring of playing on either of the two default maps, you’ve got numerous player creations to choose from, with more on the way.

Another welcome new feature is Missions, which allow you to perform basic labor for other local farmers in exchange for cold, hard cash. If managing your own farm is too intimidating, you can simply drive around the map and perform these Missions, which serve to accomplish several goals; 1) provide insight on the various aspects of crop farming routines; 2) introduce various equipment and their uses; 3) get in a farmer’s good graces so that you can eventually purchase their property at a lower value; 4) earn some cold, hard cash. I found myself performing dozens of Missions before tending to my own farm, so that by the time I got started on business proper I felt as though I had a firm grasp on things.

Crop raising isn’t the sole extent of your responsibilities, there’s animal husbandry as well. Cows, chickens, sheep and pigs are all a part of the process, adding another layer of depth and complexity to farm management. Raising animals produces sellable product as well as the fertilizer required to nourish your crops, making this an important piece of the puzzle. And for all of you aspiring lumberjacks out there, forestry is also an option. Every new facet of the farming experience requires equally new equipment, which you’ll have to either buy or rent from the local dealer then learn how to implement. There are several dozen licensed equipment manufacturers in the game as well as hundreds of in-game and modded tools and vehicles to choose from. At some point you’ll find yourself so busy that you’ll need to hire workers to aid you with your daily tasks. Eventually you’ll end up commandeering freight trains to transport your goods, another great addition to the series. Indeed, this agri-sim is brimming with options.

As you may have deduced, a farmer’s life can be a complex one. If the above was all there was to Farming Simulator 17, it would already be an easy recommendation. But there’s so, so much more. Intentionally or not, the virtual world that your farmer resides in — and indeed your farmer himself — are flawed in ways that border on Goat Simulator-esque self-parody. For example, the simple act of driving a vehicle — a game mechanic that we’ve expected some degree of precision from for at least a decade now — is inexplicably touchy and borderline uncontrollable at high speeds. When you do inevitably wreck your trusty ol' pickup, you’ll find a distinct lack of real-world physics, damage modeling or in-game reaction. This means that you can plow over pedestrians without fear of reprisal, and that crashing into a tree or a brick wall at top speed is basically the same as braking really, really hard. The vehicular shenanigans don’t end there, park your tractor in the middle of a busy street and traffic will pile up quickly, even though there is an open lane available for your fellow motorists to easily get around you.

You create your in-game farmer avatar by choosing your gender and the color of flannel shirt you want to wear inside your overalls (for males). Further customization may be a moot point as your farmer is rarely seen, he is usually in a vehicle and is always in first-person when outside the vehicle. Still, it would have been nice to offer some officially licensed apparel to accompany the dozens of licenses included in the game. Would I love my farmer to rock a Case IH trucker cap? Of course! Then again, this is Farming Simulator we're talking about and not a rural fashion show.

As it turns out, your farmer is a Superman of sorts. He requires no food, no drink, and no sleep. He can get involved in bone-crushing high-speed collisions or fall from the greatest of heights without obtaining as much as a flesh wound. He can even walk on water, which incidentally serves to make this game a passable Jesus sim. In a nutshell your farmer is invincible, there’s nothing in this digital landscape which can do him harm. This is probably intentional as the focus is supposed to be on practical farm management as opposed to whatever inspired jackassery you may be plotting whenever you’re not busy cultivating oilseed radish. In any case, it does makes for some hilarious episodes should you ever grow bored with life on the ranch.

And then there’s the gold. You see, many maps are littered with gold nuggets, which serve as a scavenger hunt type of mini-game with a decent amount of reward. These nuggets are quite shiny and far easier to locate than you might imagine (find the first 10 and you’ll see what I mean), they are usually found in another farmer’s backyard or other blatantly obvious hiding spots. This led me to question whether every other person in Goldcrest Valley was legally blind or if I was trespassing and stealing from them. Perhaps both.

Despite the comical lack of attention to in-world detail, Farming Simulator 17 succeeds on every account that it aspires to. It is an incredibly deep management sim which sheds light on a profession that quite honestly, more people need to be educated about. A farmer’s life can be a difficult one, and this game does shed a small amount of light on what these hard-working folk go through day-in and day-out just to put food on our tables. Farmers are real-life everyday heroes, just don’t expect them to be very good at basketball.

[h1]Grow already![/h1]

[b]Disclaimer[/b]
Trust me I am not really into farming, I like technology, but I do like a good simulation and that is what we have here.

I bought this title because another friend owned it too and we both bought it to support the Swiss-developer behind it, since we both think it is great our small country makes cool games too.
 
[b]Overview[/b]
Ever wondered how it is to be a farmer? Me neither, but I gave it a try and was surprised by the depth of gameplay you find here.

You basically start off on your farm with some equipment to start with.
Then you do reap your crops and plant them again, you will have to manage your finances by selling your produce at good prices to invest in better equipment to improve the daily work.

[b]Rating[/b]
8/10 for regular Gamers
9/10 for the Farmers who cannot get enough and want to have even better equipment as in RL :)

[b]The highlights[/b]
[list]
[*] Detailed Maps
[*] Many vehicle's and utilities to invest in
[*] Several different crops
[*] Nice graphics
[/list]

[b]The lowlights[/b]
[list]
[*] Gameplay tends to get repetitive (grindy), but until then you spent many hours
[/list]

[b]Multiplayer[/b]
+Yes!
You can play online with your friends and manage a Farm together.
It is a lot of fun to co-ordinate together or do fun/stupid stuff instead.
Played this with 2 friends and each of us had a speciality

[b]Mods[/b]
+Yes!
You can find mods on the Game-Homepage or from other sites on the internet.
The mods range from new equipment, new Maps, UI or helpers for your daily business.
Installation is basically copy the zip into the right directory, not to complicated.

[b]Microtransactions/DLC[/b]
There are no microtransactions.
The developer offers additional content as DLC, you decide if it is worth it or not.

[b]Summary[/b]
I honestly started to appreciate the job of a farmer even more after playing this game.
It seriously gives you a different experience of the produce you tend to buy simply at the grocery-store.

The big list of equipment gives you plenty goals to set yourself and grow your farm further and further.
This game is a well-done simulation and you should give it a try even if hard-core gamers might think this one seems casual.

The possibility to expand your game with many mods is also a big plus.

This game showed up in my recommended list and I kind of laughed it off thinking "how fun could a farming sim be". Well, it was on sale and I have always been a gear head and like trucks/tractors/machinery so I pulled the trigger and let me tell you its far from my first expectations. First off, this game is what you make it. If you want to farm every inch of dirt you own, the game allows you to do that. If you find that tedious (like me), you can hire out the work to your farm hands and focus on managing the farm. 

So, if you like: 
-Driving highly detailed tractors and machinery.
-Sandbox and Simulation games.
-Being in charge of a buisness / managing a company.
-Casual gameplay that holds your attention but allows you to pause/save/take a break at any time.
Than this game is for you.

Also, I must add that the modding aspect of the game is awesome. It refeshes the game with new and free content/maps which further extends the playability of the game. This is why you see people with hundreds to thousands of hours on this game.

Bought this because I liked Farmville and farming in general.  It has about the right amount of things you have to do for farming and single player.  However, my biggest reason for getting this was Co-op with two other people.  Tried that for a while and found out co-op was useless.  

1)  Only the owner of the farm gets any money/rewards.  Your friends get nothing.

2)  You can no longer do jobs on other farms for money.  So if I have my three fields growing, then my friends are just sitting there or playing "tractor joust" or something.  That's only fun for so long.

So while I liked running around in Co-op, it ended up seemingly totally pointless.  If just the host gets rewards, then why bother?  I'd rather play something where the visitors at least get something for helping me.  So really this game is only good for single player, which gets boring pretty quick without friends.  So I can't recommend it unless your looking for just single player.  I will say that at least it does have a good choice of difficulties, which most games don't.

My PSU died whilst playing this game (obviously not blaming the game)... But I wasn't even mad because I was so relaxed while farming. No doubt I'd be freaking out if I was playing something else with tension. 

Also, if you somewhat enjoy farming in other games like Minecraft, DayZ or enjoy watching your farm help growth in AOE, Civ.... Cut out the middle man and try this game. It's VERY methodical once you grasp the fundamentals. 

My only gripe is the lack of peril. There's limited risk and no pressure. You'll be able to think of dozens of problems farmers may face and sadly you won't see any. The harder difficulty presents financial challenge but from what I've play on normal so far, I can't imagine ever LOSING my farm somehow. That being said, there are mods to add challenges.

Either way, I recommend this game, it's a great way to detox from mainstream, action packed, AAA gaming.

1) Lately I've been really keen on games that let you customize and open - world decisions.  Games that you aren't restricted to a set path.  I bought FS17 on a whim when it was on sale and fell in love with it - to my own surprise.

2) I've always been a community organizer and so knew that this game is far better when played with other people.  Sure I'm a nerd because I game so much, and play D&D, but it blew me away how much I enjoyed FS17.  Not something I ever thought I'd like.  I think what pulled me in is the fact that it isn't scripted.  There is no "What should i do next" hand holding.  It's an open-ended relaxing game where you get to drive big awesome machines.  At my prime I was spending every evening playing FS17 when running the server for several hours.  When the server was very popular I would easily spend 3-4 hours a night playing.  Much longer on the weekends.

3) Our server was a little more relaxed then other multiplayer servers.  We aimed to have a "community" as opposed to a "simulation" of farming.  We recognized we were all gamers.  We would have community events in game and invite everyone to join.  Everyone took a round of shots while we drove trucks around town doing deliveries.  Any time someone crashed we wouldn't "reset" the vehicles, we had to go get tow bars and pull them out.  Made for lots of laughs.  We switched maps 4-5 times during the time I hosted the server.  Each map filled a different need and made by excellent map makers in the community like Stevie and Dajnet.  Most recently we were on Pleasant Valley v3.1, a map by Dajnet.  It is an amazing map and allowed us to support several more players on our server as the map alone has 6 different standalone farms.

The only thing I noticed with this game as opposed to other communities I've created in other games is the turnover rate is very high.  People don't stick around FS17 as much as other communities.  They get anxious to try new maps, or other games, or play more casually.  Not as many 'gamers' play FS17 but there were a handful.

4) Recommended to be heavily modded.  The vanilla version of the game is not designed very well when it comes to multiplayer.  The game really comes alive and fun when you start installing mods.  Very unique maps with new machines, new equipment and tractors, new manufacturing features.  The vanilla game gets repetitive and boring very quickly.  But Mods make it a much better experience with thousands of activities to do, depending on your combination of maps and mods.

In addition, I played for several months with mouse and Keyboard but the game felt new again after I purchased a Wheel, pedals, and a Joystick.

5)Other servers that are legitimately organized seem to be a lot different.  Everyone has an opinion when they transfer from an old server, "my server used to do it this way...".  So there is a lot of variation.  Some servers don't care about realism so they will mod their machines to go ridiculously fast, or hold way too much materials.  Other servers have TOO MUCH realism in my opinion, and don't allow players to drive anywhere but on the roads with certain vehicles.  We were somewhere in between.  The only thing I wish Giants would improve would be their multiplayer features.  It was really difficult to keep an ongoing server going with limited access to how in game funds work.  Lots of mods helped fix this. 

As a result, I know several servers even ran the game with a bunch of spreadsheets, and tracked their expenses out of game.  I did that for too long in EVE online that when I switched to FS17 I wanted a much more casual experience.  So we made it work on our server with mods, even though it wasn't perfect.

A great gaming experience all around, and will appeal to gamers that least expect it.

Farm Simulator 17...

What can I say about this game? Its def farming 101 if you know nothing about farming, but its def the basics of farming. I'm a bit disappointed in a game that calls itself a simulator and boasts detail of real trucks and other stuff but yet doesn't really care about anything like ground nutrient levels or the such. How about a soil sampling system that will allow you to monitor the PH levels or tell you how much bacteria is in the soil? I mean simple stuff like basic nutrient levels of your soils are key to whether or not your crops should grow.

To me this game feels more like an advertising platform for the various agricultural companies and their equipment than an ACTUAL farm simulation. Its all about the big trucks and driving around. Its more of an arcade than a sim game. I mean, plow your field, fertilize it, plant your seeds, wait some time (which is controllable by settings) then harvest your crops and deliver to the highest bidders. That's pretty much it. If you want stuff that makes it easier to do these various steps, buy bigger equipment. Can you trade to other players? Nope. Multiplayer seems more like a "helping hand" type setup where your friends can come into your game and help you farm. You give them some money to play with and they buy equipment and farm stuff for you. When they leave, everything they got or money they made (or is left over after they joined) is yours and comes back to you. There's really no point in giving them any money unless you're lazy and you don't want to buy stuff for people helping you all day long and you want to get work done on your own. Nevermind the fact that the mission system for the NPC players is disabled in multiplayer. What's up with that?? Why can't you and your friends do those missions too? Seems entirely illogical to have those missions disabled. It gives you more things to do!

Yes it looks good, and its an easy farming game. No worries about being stuck in the mud if you stick to the roads and your fields, but to me, if you're going to call yourself a simulator, how about you simulate all aspects of farming? Wheather, soil nutrients, chemical systems, different types of fertilizers, the simple ability to even clean your farm equipment after its all dirty... All of these things are part of farming that are entirely missed. Granted I haven't had much game time and maybe I just haven't seen these things. Feel free to correct me in comments, but to me these things should be more outlined in a refined simulator type game.

For them to call this a simulation of what its like to be a farmer, you get a thumbs down. This isn't a simulator for farming. Its more of an advertisment for farm equipment companies than a farming simulator. Its too late for a refund now. So hopefully if others are looking at this game they'll take heed that if they're looking for realism, look elsewhere. You won't find it here. Not even close. There is so much depth to farming its unreal. I work for an agricultural chemical company IRL. I know a thing or two about farming and they don't even come close to scratching the surface with this game.

My hours in this game speak for themselves. I love it, the graphics are immersive, the gameplay is fulfilling and the in-game mod hub allows for endless, almost instant, and dramatic changes. If you are looking for a casual, relaxing game this is it for sure. The base game is good for 100's of hours of entertainment and with mods and the available DLC you get 100's of hours more. Video games used to be a way to escape the stresses of life and unwind and FS17 is exactly that!

I am going to rate this potivie for two reasons;
1)
Amazing graphics and attention to detail. I know farmers who have looked at this and couldnt believe the detail on equipment.
Is a great game to play and explore the life of a farmer without actually having to get you hand dirty or wait an actual 6-8 months for your crops to grow (but that is a option in the game menu). 
2) 
After a couple... a few... a lot of drinks, for some reason this game is amazing! I have at least 3 friends that I know when they are too drunk to walk but want to play a game, Farm Sim is where we go. I dont know why, but its just FUN.

The game can be a bit boring at times and once you get things down pat, your basically working just to keep the farm going. Nwe equipment is fun to begin with but just like that new phone you got the other day, the excitement wears off. 
Grab it on sale and have some fun as they really put some great work into it. But dont expect to have 100 hours flash by and wonder where the time went.
But i still recommend this as it is some fine work. Maybe just not my thing, even though its still installed - just in case I have one too many and want a game to play.

though it has some issues.

and second it has some little niggly things i can't realy put my head around for not being adressed.

Farming Simulator 17 is the most unbelievably tedious gameplay experience I've ever had, where most things should be automated by a worker so you can focus on farm ownership and growth, and not farm micromanagement. This game needs to be stripped down, automated, and made way easier to play, where processes are explained and spelled out to improve the overall gameplay payoff.  I'm surprised there are DLC's to this game, when the problem is the base game, and not the equipment, because the equipment I was looking for is not available in the base game, DLC's, or in any of the mods, because swathing and rock picking is not a part of the simulation, and those two things takes up a large portion of all farm life.

In order for me to recommend this game, here is a list of things that would need to change:

⦁Land in North America is subdivided by the quarter section and is on a grid, and this game will never feel like a true farming simulation and I will never recommend it, until there is a farm out on a homestead surrounded by quarter sections of land and grid roads, and you get to put things where you want them when you buy them and don't have to go get them.  Do a random google search of anywhere in the bread basket.

⦁Fields need to be rotated with different crops due to nutrient depletion and different fields have different soils that produce certain crops better than others, and crops only grow once a year, and that should be the focus of the entire game, land management per year along with organizing staff.   This game kind of encourages destroying the land for the sake of money, instead of taking care of it, even with fertizilier and planting oilseed, and it also treats workers as though they come and go by your command instead of encouraging a team effort and the importance of maintaining a skilled labor force, which is the entire struggle with farming, getting the most value for your dollar in terms of lowest input costs in the productivity of your equipment and workers to the highest returns in the price of the grain and animals.  So, creating some sort of labor section to the game where different workers have different levels of abilities and come at different costs would really add to everything, for example, the more you get a worker to do a certain task, the better they get at it.  I'd want workers for absolutely everything that is done in this game (transport, livestock, grain, and mowing), a fully automated simulation that you could just watch play out and check your financials and adjust as you go.

⦁All crops are measured, bought, and sold by the bushel, and should be in this game. All grain is graded by quality as well, for example number 1 wheat, number 2 wheat, and feed wheat, as well as dockage from contamination, which is in relation to weather and how well you farm/enjoy gambling.  Weather is a massive part of farming, and it's all that farmers talk about next to complaining about the government.  So, the connection between a wet early spring and good yield should play into the game, along with a long or short, hot, cold or wet growing season, and temperature during harvest would really add to the gameplay, but only if everything was automated.

⦁I like the competing markets, I just don't like that I have to drive to them, that should be automated by a worker or grain should just simply sell like you sell animals, with a touch of a button.  Also, do you have any idea how much more complicated it is to transport and sell livestock than grain? There are livestock auctions and breeding problems that are totally ignored in this game.

⦁No one ever went to the retail section of an outlet mall to buy farm machinery, lol!  Farm machinery is ordered from an industrial warehouse in your local town or city and delivered to your farm; you don't even need to go pick it up in real life, so why do you have to in this game?  You only go to pick up parts that break down.  It's simulating something that doesn't even exist, and it's super tedious having to go back and forth to pick up everything over and over again, it's such a huge amount of wasted gameplay time, when again, it should be automated by a worker or simply placed on your farm.

⦁Why can't you buy feed for your animals and have a worker take care of them?

⦁Why are there no auction sales?
 
⦁Why are there no quonsets, no grain bins, no augers, no swathers, no grain trucks, no harrow packers, and no rock pickers?  That is the basis of all farming, and it's not even in this game hilariously enough! Or John Deere?  You can't even call it farming without John Deere.  No Versatile Tractors either? No gas and diesel tanks you can put on your farm? You can't dig a well with a pump for your animals? No hemp, camelina, peas, lentils, clover for the bee hives to make real honey, flax, mustard, canary seed, rye, or oats?

⦁Why can't you set up the parameters of the entire simulation and then watch it run very quickly to see how your simulation will play out and then stop it at parts to adjust things and then speed it up again?  I'd prefer a Sim City style simulation more, than all the running back and forth.  Cultivating, seeding, and combining is all too tedious and slow and must be sped up but there's no way to do so at all, it's all at one slow speed.  120x only speeds up the growing season and not the automated gameplay, which doesn't make any sense, simulation wise, a true simulation works very closely with time of day in order to maximize output, instead of harvesting half a field with 3 days going by in the process. As an example, when harvesting canola there's a very tight window during the day when you can harvest, as you have to check the moisture content to make sure its less than 8% before you go out to harvest in the morning and before you finish in the evening, because if it exceeds that, it will heat and spoil in the bin and will get rejected at the elevator, unless you have a dryer at your farm.

⦁The breakdown of your financials is clunky and poorly organized, which is one of the most realistic parts of this game, because that's kinda how farmers are.

⦁The zoom over a tractor with an attachment, like a tractor and cultivator, doesn't zoom over the middle of the new object, but remains zoomed over the middle of the tractor, and doesn't allow you to see behind the cultivator when zoomed in close. Adjust the center point of a unit with an attachment to the center of the newly combined unit instead of remaining centered on the vehicle.

I found this to be a frustrating gameplay experience because you have to do the jobs that are the gopher's responsibility which are tedious and annoying when you could be focusing on your plan of growth for the future.  I'd rather play a farming simulator that had a different focus and style of gameplay altogether, like Sim City, that organized the farm by the year and broke down what had to be done by the season and could speed through seasons like winter where less is happening.  Unless they created a homestead far from town surrounded by quarter sections of land, added an automated worker to go get new equipment, sell grain, and move stuff around, and made everything less tedious and less hands on, and sped up the gameplay, and allowed you to set the parameters for the simulation, showed the depletion of soil quality on your land, showed the increase in staff ability and development, had more crop varieties, and added swathers, augers, grain bins, grain trucks and rock pickers, then this would be fun for me and a more realistic simulation.  As it is, it just simulates something that doesn't happen in the real world, and I mentioned nothing about the dangers of raising animals in such confined spaces and no option for the type of cattle to be raised.

Please note, I played 80+ hours to give this game an honest shot and it's super addicting but overall, more frustrating than enjoyable gameplay, for me.

Having never played any of the previous Farming Simulator games, or anything like them, I had no idea whether I would like this game or think it was tedious. Excellent variety of vehicles, plenty of stuff to do but never boring, gorgeous graphics, just the right amount of micromanagement, and more relaxing than Bob Ross on valium. I highly recommend playing with a controller, as the keyboard would not be great for driving.

You're better off using the defaults because you're going to be bouncing in and out of your games like this is your boy's ride.

I seldom take the time or effort to leave commentary on a game.  This is the exception.  Farming Simulator 17 is one of the best games I have ever played in terms of sheer endless gameplay opportunities.  The price range for the base game and DLC is below standard average, proving that the company cares more about providing players with a quality product than to fleece money from customers.  Additionally, the Modding community for this title is vast and competent.  10/10.
I love this game and is  the best.

I have come to FS17 as a previous player of FS15.  I held off on buying this as the one thing that really annoyed me about FS15 was the lack of head tracking support for it.  It ws the one thing that I felt that it really needed to make it perfect and now FS17 has it!  Yay!

Having bought FS17 it is everything I had hoped that it would be and more.  Not only is head tracking enabled but several things that were enabled as slightly clunky mods in FS15 are now in FS17 as standard.

For those who are completely new to the Farming Simulator series, the game is, as the name suggests, a simulation of many aspects of farming.  The game is first- or third-person view and allows you to farm using a wide variety of farm machinery such as tractors, combine harvesters, trucks, cars, and mowers.  You also have the ability to get out and walk around your farm on foot and there are a few, limited, activities that can be carried out without a big machine to help you.  

The game covers arable farming, animal farming, and forestry, and each of these go through growth and harvest cycles, each requiring different processes throughout.  Having cultivated, planted, fertilised, and harvested your crop you can then sell the harvest for cash with which to buy better equipment, more fields, pay off your bank loan, and buy seeds and other consumables to get your next crop going.  

This is not a game for those who are looking for a massive adrenaline dump.  It's a slow burn, enjoyable game, that will seem fairly dull to begin with until you realised that you just lost the weekend.  I have seen some reviews that describe this game as boring and I can understand that viewpoint, but it's either something you will enjoy or you won't.  It's not for everyone.  I find it extremely relaxing (except for stacking bales, that's really quite tricky and tense).

For those who have played FS15, things that I am really impressed with in this version are such things as head-tracking having native support (that's a total winner for me), having the option to have the vehicle auto-start on getting in it or having to press a button to start/stop the engine, and working wing mirrors on vehicle.  For me the combination of working mirrors and head-tracking are superb.  I have tried reversing trailers in real life and it is really hard.  In FS17 you will have lots and lots of opportunities to practise your trailer-reversing skills and in order to do that properly you need wing mirrors and the ability to look between them quickly and easily.  With these enabled it is very, very good.  I would recommend getting a head-tracker and steering wheel with pedals for the full experience.  It is possible to customise the controls so that the steering wheel and pedals only work when in-vehicle thus removing an annoyance from GTA5 where your character would gently drift left or right if the wheel wasn't completely centred when you were on foot.

In addition to the stock elements, the game has a huge number of mods available accessible in-game.  I have not played any of the stock farms yet, I have played from the outset on a farm called Coldborough Park Farm which is based on a real farm in Herefordshire.  As a Brit I absolutely love the fact that I can play the game in the same sort of countryside I can see driving to work.  There are very few games with hedges (yeah, I know, a small thing, right?) but they are a huge feature of the English landscape and it really makes the game seem realistic.  I have 17 hours in-game on FS17 and I have not had a chance to try everything yet: I haven't tried forestry or animal husbandry, and I haven't been able to do any of the missions (as I haven't found any fields that have them yet), but from what I have played the game is superb!

There are a few flaws.  The hired help is a drunkard who frequently drives my combine harvester into a ditch and then just leaves it there, or, at best, leaves great swathes of crops un-harvested, and he charges through the nose.  The fields are huge (I'm not sure if this is really a flaw) so working them can be a daunting task.  I liked some of the smaller fields in FS15 Hagenstedt as they allowed me to do quick turn-arounds, but this is more realistic.  It's one of the reasons I am willing to hire drunken-Bob to do the harvesting.  

If you liked FS15 I would say that it is definitely worth the upgrade to FS17.  The graphics are much, much better, the gameplay is better, and lots of features are enabled that made FS15 just not quite as good as it should have been.

If you fancy having a go at farming, give this a go.  I was initially put off the idea of playing a farming simulator as I could imagine my farmer friends scoffing at the idea until one of my farmer friends told me that he was pretty well addicted to it.  That was good enough for me.  Of course, it's one thing trying to wrestle the linkage of a three-ton trailer onto a tractor in freezing sleet in the middle of a muddy field in February, and another to sit at a PC in the warm, sipping coffee and doing it with the press of a button.  I know which I prefer.

While having a few flaws, this game is by far the best of the Farming Simulator series. It has the best graphics, the most equipment, and the most crops. That being said, I am going to review this game itself, and not compare it to its predecessors. 

There is a very large amount of content included in the base game. You get two maps*, one in America and one in Eastern Europe. You get equipment for growing, harvesting, and selling 8 types of crops*, wheat, barly, canola, corn, soy beans, potatos, sugar beats, and grass. You also get machines to take care of two types of animals, pigs and cows. Finally, you get a wide range of forestry equipment, to harvest, load, plant, and transport trees, as well as woodchipping. Although it will take a few hours of doing the boring work, you should soon have enough things to do that you will no longer be bored. 

That said, this game is never really exiting. It's fun, but in a relaxing, role-play sort of way. It can be very educational as well, but it's not hard core enough to turn anyone into a proffesional farmer. 

Also included in the game is a menue for downloading free addons (mods) made by the community. These include maps, equipment, features, and other things that contribute to gameplay very nicely. 

You can even play with up to 15 other people in the multiplayer mode. The servers are pretty slow, however, with long stops to syncronise every time someone joins a server. 

The physics for this game are very arcade-like, yet there are still problems often. Especially with logging, all kinds of strange things can happen. When the physics are not acting up, however, logging is a fun way to take a break from normal farming, and is made easier by you being able to pick up logs and strap them down on certain trailers, and the beds of the pickup trucks. 

Overall, I would give this game an 8 out of 10. It's not for everyone, but you should definitely try it. 

*In the "Platimun Edition" DLC, there is a new map in South America, and a new crop, sugarcane.

Holy balls, where to start. Okay. So Farming Simulator 17 is a game/simulator where you farm. Makes sense. When you first start out, you should absolutely do the tutorials. The issue with those though is that they only tell you so much. So the game has a bit of a learning curve. Which to me is a very good thing for a simulator. It's as simple or complicated as you want to make it. Want to get into the nitty-gritty of economics? You can totally do that and plan out absolutely everything. Just feel like painting some fields and driving some tractors around? Go for it. It's extremely satisfying to just drive your favorite tractor around for a while when you need a break from all the management stuff. Speaking of which, there's a lot of that in this game. And that is not a bad thing at all. It can get overwhelming at times, but it's all worth it when you finally get to afford the tractor of your dreams!

That was the TL;DR version. Moving on to the in-depth look.

So, when you first start out on a map, you start at a farm with some stuff already. Sweet! The catch is that it's heavily used stuff and is going to cost more and more to maintain as time goes on. So you should replace the old stuff with new stuff ASAP. Particularly the combine. That thing is going to bleed you dry if you hold onto it for too long. And though the game lets you lease things.....don't go that route. It start's out nice and cheap, sure. But before long you'll be paying 10,000 a day for that 60,000 tractor. Not so great. Sadly there's no Vanilla way to repair heavily used items but in all honesty this game is mostly about progression so you probably won't want to hang onto that beat up Case tractor any longer than you have to anyway. 

Once you're established with good gear and have a few fields, you will run into the problem of time. Mainly, having too much of it. Sure you could bump up the timescale, but where's the fun in that? Besides; it does more harm than good. This is where you have a few options. Assuming you don't have any mods installed yet, which you shouldn't on your first playthrough, your options will be somewhat limited in terms of making the most efficient use of your time. But that's also part of the charm. In the game you have a few things to do between tending the fields:

*Logging: You can cut down trees to sell. You can sell them straight up, you can sell them without branches, in logs, in blocks, or even as wood chips. Personally, I feel like logging can be a real PITA without mods. They've fixed a lot of the issues with the physics engine regarding logging, but some issues still remain. It CAN be fun, and often is, but not always. It's also expensive for what you get in return. If you have absolutely nothing better to do or you just really like sawing logs (heh) then by all means go for it. There are mods out there that really help with this. Check out CZ Tools if you want to kill most of the headaches associated with most of the vanilla tools.

*Grasswork: This is some of the most fun I've had in this game. Basically you mow grass. This is actually really fun and also really important for other things I will go into in a bit. Why would you do it besides for enjoyment? It's extremely beneficial to do for your farm. Grass can be used for all sorts of things. You can give it to animals, tedd it into hay and give it to animals, compact either into bales for storage or to sell (though not for very much like this), use hay for TMR, and ferment grass into silage which can be given to cows as-is, or used in TMR. You can also turn silage into Digestate, which is basically ground up decaying plant matter and has a really gross name. What would digestate be used for? Well, think about it for a second. What do cows eat? Grass. What do cows turn grass into? Manure. What can you do with it besides pouring it into Biff's car? Fertilize your fields. So basically you're taking the cows out of the equation. But the best part? Not only do you get free fertilizer (sweet!), but the game will actually PAY YOU for doing it. The catch is that unlike pellets or fertilizer juice, it goes REALLY fast. But it's free, and you actually make more money doing it in the long run, so it's worth doing. However, using the clamp silos, while neat and free, is a major pain and just feels archaic. There is a mod out on modhub that makes this step a breeze by figuratively cutting them out of the picture and giving you placeable fermenting silos that are vertical and are pretty much no-fuss. You load them with a trailer and unload them with one. However, there is one MAJOR gripe with making digestate. This has to do with loading the biomass plant. You CANNOT directly unload your trailer into the pit where the silage is put in. There really isn't a reason for this. At all. This is really stupid and makes no sense. Instead I guess you're expected to fill up a bucket loader and drive it all the way to the plant and unload it 1000 liters at a time??? Who's idea was that?! Screw that, man. But it isn't all bad. There is a workaround; it just takes longer than directly unloading the trailer into the pit and to my knowledge only works with trailers that have a grain door. Basically, you take the conveyor that can "load directly into other trailers" (the one with the big fat base on it) and set it up so that the belt drops the stuff into the pit. Then you set your trailer to unload through the grain door, back it up to the conveyor belt feed tray, and unload away. You don't have to babysit it, so you can go do other stuff, but just remember to check on it periodically. I imagine you could have several of these going at once but it just seems cumbersome for something that you could do in real life without a second thought or the need for a setup like this. Also, one final note on grasswork; you can harvest grass directly into a trailer with a forage harvester. Very nice for late game use. 

*Animals: This sort of overlaps with grasswork a bit. Basically there are four types of animals in the game: Chickens (you always have these little spies laying eggs and are really easy for a quick buck), Sheep (very easy still; just some grass and water), Cows (bit of a pain if you are making TMR which will get you the most bang for your buck; else just feed them grass or silage, straw for bedding, and water), and Pigs (hardest of them all as they require a very mixed diet, straw, and water). Animals will produce stuff (chickens lay eggs, cows make milk, dung, and slurry [eww], etc) and will breed on their own if conditions are met (they have food, water, bedding, room for more animals, eating areas are clean, etc) and either can be sold or used on the farm (dung, slurry). Even if you don't want to do any other animal, do sheep as they are extremely easy to take care of and give wool over time that can be sold for VERY high prices. 

*Poplar: I have only just started on this section, but its pretty straightforward. Basically you plant poplars on a field, and turn them into chips once they're done growing with a forage harvester. Don't know how lucrative this is yet though so I will update this once I know more.

Next I'd like to talk about the tractors and such. The first thing I'll say is that the prices for them are insane. When you have some cashflow going, it's not so bad. But when you have nothing except tattered hats and beard dirt? It's a nightmare. Enter the mods! There are hundreds of mods out there that add tractors. I recommend the ones that add Ford tractors, Fendt, New Holland, John Deere, and Zetor. The Case/IH ones are pretty good too. I love the Zetor ones out there very much. New Holland is great too. Also a lot of the time the modded tractors have added features like Interior Control (IC). Everything else is pretty good too.

Finally, the DLCs. First and foremost, yikes at that pricing! Yeesh! Crazy! Yet also 150% worth every penny. The packs add great stuff to the game and the new map is incredible

What is Farming Simulator 17? Exactly what it says on the tin. you'll wander fields in tractors, you'll manage your finances and work toward turning a profit for your crops. There is a lot to this game but like any simulator, it's hard to sell if you're not sure you want it from the get-go.

With the glut of shooting titles out there, it's nice to just tune out and enjoy the easy life. Massive selection of mods to add in new machines, maps and more help keep even the base game very interesting. The DLC offerings are very much take it or leave it.

Sure the physics might get a little janky sometimes but it's a solid title and easy to pick up for play, I suppose grind might be a better word but I'd rather a pleasant evening of trundling along to the sound of diesel engines and turning soil than cracks of sniper fire, voice chat ear rape and frustrating skill / p2w gaps a casual player wouldn't easily overcome.

It's something you do because you enjoy doing it, not because you want a leaderboard score.

Great game to play with friends - there are a couple of things I thought it was worth noting though, if you are planning to run a dedicated server
1. Don't buy the Steam version of this game as the copy to run your dedicated server. It has issues trying to launch the dedicated server. Lots of them. Just buy the game directly from Giants and the problems are completely gone.  This isn't explicitally spelled out anywhere, and I made the mistake of buying the Steam version and had to get it refunded.  Clients who are running the steam version will have no issues connecting.  It's only an issue with launching a dedicated server.
2. You must have a separate copy of the game to run a dedicated server.  This seems like an odd design choice by the developers, but not a show stopper for me - merely annoying.

Other than that - great game.  Graphics are on par with the rest of the entries in the series. No technical issues to speak of. Game works great and delivers on all fronts.  If I had to make a complaint, it would be that the developer didn't include crossplay with the Xbox One version of this game.  That would be cool.

If you've played the previous games, you'll know all about this. There are definite improvements to the engine and at this point I think a lot of mods have been updated to work in 17. Just being able to drop crops into piles wherever was a big improvement. There are some disappointments (the train setup in the Westbridge map is a big WTF? moment) but they're minor in comparison. I'm not a big fan of the whole "let's force you to buy a whole new game every couple of years" mentality but I also can't say this isn't a great upgrade, especially if it's on sale like it is.

For those who've never played this, you'll get this if you've wanted to run a farm without the reality of how tough it is for small family-run farms to actually survive. You're doing a lot of work (though there are mods and helper AIs to help with most tasks) and you've got to keep track of when to plant, when to harvest, etc. while storing your grains until the price is right for you to sell it. I've loved farming games since I played SimFarm back in the day. I'd tried some other sims but this one was the one that had the least bugs and most selection (especially with mods/workshop items to add on). It can take some getting used to but in the end there's just something fun about buying a new tractor, getting to use your new wheel loader while mixing total mixed rations for your cows, and just watching your harvest come in. It's not for everyone but you'll know if it's for you.

I ordered this game before the 1st of November which meant that I got the Challenger MT700E Field Viper and the Valtra T-Series Cow Edition for free! Just to start things off these two tractors are an amazing addition to the game that I am quite thankful to have. 

The two base maps themselves (Goldcrest Valley and Sosnovka) are great starting maps and are quick to memorize. Even if you do get bored of these maps, you have the Giants ModHub to use to find other good maps that may give you a bit more of a challenge.

Also thanks to the ModHub, there are also many other mods available for almost anything you can imagine and they're all so easy to install and use.

Multiplayer is also quite good as well considering I don't exactly have the BEST of computers to play on, but the game still manages to run quite smoothly.

I was really impressed with how well this game runs though, as I said before I don't have a great computer where I run most games around 20FPS but Giants have done a GREAT job at making the game run smoothly as I can easily hit 40FPS and usually play with medium graphics.

Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who wants to pass time, mess around, have some fun with friends or set up their own entire farm- Either a crop farm, Sheep, Cow, Pig farm or even get into the forestry business.

Another dull, run-of-the-mill iteration that's not worth the price, where the most effort went into a high quality render as game trailer video.

Driving is still garbage, the side mirrors are useless zoomed-in wank, physics elements are shoddy, vanilla gameplay is unbearable, no borderless window mode, no proper wheel/pedal/shifter support, alt-tabbing out of the game activates controller axises, no force feedback, the original Pacman ghosts had better AI than the AI traffic in this game.

Less than half-arsed money sink mechanics (vehicle maintenance) as a disillusioned attempt to add depth, no new features worth mentioning, logging equipment is trash (grabbing logs), sound engine is still trash (e.g. super loud birds, water, animal barks) and volumes can't be properly customised (e.g. engine vs environment, "environment" is the volume for everything when you're "outside of a vehicle"). As a minor missing feature, no Steam Workshop integration for mods.

Can't rebind keys or set a multitude of options without the game reloading, having to be in the main menu and not in a game. Multiplayer is still an absolute joke with the game pausing for everyone to synchronise data for several minutes. Now they're bringing out a Platinum "expansion" for EUR 18,- that owners of the game have to pay full price as reward for their support and loyalty, while new players get the base game + the expansion for the old base game's price in a bundle.

They've been iterating Farming Simulator for a decade, you'd expect they know how to make a good game by now. 

Nope.

They really just come every two years to grab a load of cash for a bland cookie made of manure, with a few overpriced DLC sprinkles. It's better than the bottom shelf "Simulator" trash games, but I really hope GIANTS drowns in the mud(*) pit they've created, once one or two competitors pave the road to greener pastures.

Definitely more fun and addicting than you would think.  Farming, after all, is not the most exciting thing to do hour after hour.  I was sceptical but bought the game on a rainy weekend for "something different". Now 300+ hours later I still love it.    

More properly, the game is a tractor and implement simulator. The tedium of droning up and down the fields have been replaced with lots of different tractors and implements to try out in the basic game and tons more in easy to install mods.    Giants got the balance right.  Enough variety to keep a person interested in all the different facets and operations on a farm and just enough work to make a good harvest very satisfying.  Several different crops requiring different types of machinery and a few animals  having varyious needs provide even more opportunities to try out new equipment and provide clear goals for your crop farming activities.  If these are not enough there is also logging equipment in the game that can provide some rewarding challenge.

Farm Simulator 17 also offers enough flexibility to satisfy many different types of gameplay.  You can be very serious and plan out your crops for maximum yeilds and most efficient operations or just "play" with different equipment and see how it all works out.  

The physics model is quite "generous" and playful.  You won't have to worry about getting stuck too often.    The game definitely does not punish you for being a bit sloppy with your driving.  The graphics are great and sunsets on some of the maps are simply beautiful.

A very well rounded and adaptable game that provides more entertainment than it should. You might even find yourself curious about how a combine really works under the hood or browsing a tractor dealerships website "just to look"...   

Highly recomended.
this game rules

Here is my review for farming sim 17.

Pros...
1. It can run on a potato powered by another larger potato feeding on only the power of the sun and moon and magic because the graphics are really like not good.

2. You can drive stuff around if you cant afford a real farm.

3. You can spend an endless time doing what seems like absolutly nothing and when you stop life just has this new sparkle.

4. When your waiting for your server to synce you can grab some food or travel the world(depending on the length of synce).

5. Mods make the endless grind a little better.

6.The community is meh at best but that leaves YOU the room to improve it because it pretty much consists of 50 or less players.

7. You wont have to learn much if you played 2015 because it pretty much that with more DLC and a higher price which is very nice if your a vet player.

8. Did I allready say it really helps you get a sense of pacience because of the "druging" gameplay and the utter lack of exitement. Looking at a wall almost is FUN after an hour of this game.

9. If you buy this you will be ready for farming sim 18 becasue there will be nothing different except the price tag.

10. There are money mods that let you make millions in seconds so any "real" money earned from gameplay feels meaningless.

Cons...
I guess you could say that there are a few bugs but other than that this games is pure enjoyment, and I really suggest that you buy it for its full price just to support the great DEVs behind the game. There is relly nothing that will ever compare to this game and franchise in quality or price and I see no better way to was..t.t err, I mean spend your hard earned cash. Its so fun.

When I come across games with "Simulator" in the name, I am often presented with a glance of the actual experience while being immersed in zen-like experience.  City builders, business management and vehicle simulations are complex enough to show you the real thing while being simple enough to enjoy it at your own pace.  Farming Simulator is one of those games that offers an awesome representation that covers shows you what you can expect to find on a farm and give you a taste of the administrative side of things, but plays things a little on the casual side of simulation.

In short - Farming Simulator takes the strangely relaxing experience of ubran planning and business management games then throws some serious agricultural hardware into the mix.  It's like your very own zen garden where you use Tonkas instead of rakes.

Is this worth purchasing?


Put it this way, I'm new to the franchise and after my few sessions messing around I am looking to get a copy of the Switch Edition it's that engaging!

I greatly enjoy the game and there are literally thousands of mods available both public and private mods that can keep it interesting enjoyable.

However there is much about this particular series of simulators that needs improvement. I have played every single release in the farming simulator series and there are some things that are always lacking. There is no dynamic ground effects from the tire tracks and many games already have that implemented so it shouldn't be too much to ask for a farming game to include it because afterall working in less than ideal conditions is a big part of farming. Also except for not being able to harvest while it's raining there are no weather effects in the base game and again that is a big part of farming. 

On another note the helper system....has always and most likely will always be complete garbage. If the field isn't perfectly square they are utterly useless and end up wasting you more time than they save. It simply cannot be that difficult to scan each field on a map and put that information into a helper code so they are able to actually do their jobs in the fields properly. 

The developers of this series need to seriously sit down and work on some of the main aspects of farming and make these games more of a simulator and less of an arcade style game. They seriously are going to have an extremely difficult time surpassing Cattle and Crops when it's released and they may not win fans back when it's time to release FS 2019 if they don't make some drastic improvements.

100+ hours, and more to come. I have thoroughly enjoyed this game. If you want something to relax and play then buy it!. I can't speak for the DLC, as I feel they are too costly, but with the modding community pumping out great stuff, there is almost no end to what you can do to manage the best farm you can make. You can be realistic, or just worry about the financial part, as I do, and work to have a farm with the highest quaility around! You can use your singleplayer game online, as long as the others have the same mods. Mods have never been easier to install, simple DL in the mods section, or copy paste from online. Then just activate before you load the game. Everything looks amazing, with great detail, and works as intended.

A fantastic simulator, tremendous depth and realism and a real celebration of machines.

The variety of machines that you can use with all their combinations of expansions and attachments etc in a variety of realistic tasks on the farm are really great fun to use and operate. 

One of my favourite things about this game is that it has plenty of variety - whether you want to farm crops, or just do missions for other farmers, or do logging (which can be done with very little equipment right up to some fantastically fun equipment) or look after animals - or do all three and just chop and change between them!

Some FANTASTIC mods on the mod hub as well - the Massey Ferguson tractor and accessory pack is a must-have imho, and it's free, incredibly.

I run a server for subscribers to my channel and it's popular among subs - great fun getting lots of people together to operate the farm, and makes longer jobs much quicker when you have four people ploughing a field together!

Definitely recommend this, one of my favourites.

So from Train Sim and European/American Truck Simulators to the more pastoral delights of farming, Hey a drivable train, the train simmers will not like as it looks nothing like any that I'm aware, however it works in context and hunt for a mod that will give a more real looking loco and consist.
Hey trucks, all sorts of trucks. Well not all truckers get to go round Europe or vast swathes of the US, some prefer to work closer to home, but before you get any work you stuff to haul. OK the real point of this game is the endless cycle that is farming, Plant, nurture, reap, plant and all the other activities to help crops along to being a movable, sellable commodity.
The vanilla game has lots of Tractors and equipment to help with the task in hand, the modding community, if you wish, has even more, however do be aware that some of these mod sites contain more bugs that a biological warfare lab and almost all have the same mods. (This games modding community would do well to look at the Train Simulator mod/reskins sites and learn).
Some mods are also available in game or from the games official site, and this includes tools that will help to to "Prod about under the hood" to make your Farming life easier/more difficult/realistic and a fair amount of addition maps to play, the base game includes two maps, with a third soon to be added as a "Platinum Add-On"
How you play is up to you, you can go total sandbox with a small mod to help the in game finances or you can can go full on difficult.

I've logged quite a lot hours into FS17 so its about time I done a review. I've owned every version since FS2011 (This is the first I got via Steam). Its truly great game from Giants Software and with many improvements over FS15. New features that improve the gameplay include the a option to lease machinery as well as buy, the ability to pick small objects by hand which is great picking up those fiddly small bits of trees when logging. There's also new crops in sunflowers and soybeans as well as a new animal type, pigs which seem to breed like rabbits. In one of the vanilla maps theres even drivable trains to transport large amount of crops and logs around.

   The missions are now more meaningful and related to farming. Instead of before where you just transported pallets around the map, you now do work on fields that are not owned by you. This has the added benefit of having crops growing in all fields rather than having them empty until you buy them which gives the map a more dynamic feel.

   The game with its two maps is great fun to play as it is out of the box but you would be missing out on one of the best aspects of this game; the mods. There is a continuously growing number of mods that are available, most of which are very simple to install. Theres the mods that add extra maps and machinery which improve the variety and choice in the game. Then there's the gameplay mods such as GPS mod, courseplay, and 'follow me' mod that help make tasks that little bit easier. Then there's ones like the seasons mod than make  the game more realistic. Best of all these mods don't cost a cent unlike a certain train game where you have to get the credit card out when you want more content.

  There are many other Farming games appearing but FS17 is still the best so far. Nice graphics and runs flawlessly for me with no issues. Definitely worth a buy.
